Simply choosing the correct size at the beginning, will save you so much time when youâ€™re ready to save and export your images for the world to see!While several factors go into making an image its very best, color is one of the mostÂ essential ingredients. Color psychology has proven time and time again that we can convey emotions simply by using a particular color!Last year, I did a two-month study on the popularity of a given color in CoScheduleâ€™s graphics. Since we typically use a three-color palette for our blog graphics, I was able to give appropriate rankings to each of the three colors usedÂ to see how they each performed.I quickly realized that certain colors might be performing betterÂ simply because we use them more often, so I then compared the popularity percentage to the usage percentageÂ to find an overall color grade.Basically, I nerded out and used data to see what colors performed the best.Use a graph like this to review and test your color schemes.At the end of my study, we found that blue and green were our highest performing colors! If we look at color psychology, both of these colors reflect a calm, clean, comforting presence which seems toÂ be the perfect match to the experience we want our readers to have, especially if theyâ€™re new to the CoSchedule blog. Blue is also one of our brand colors.The other two top-performing colors were none other then red and orange. While blue and green provide a safe, calm place for our readers, orange and red are perfect complements becauseÂ they grab our audienceâ€™s attention and spark theirÂ interest.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Psychology tells us that red and orange represent passion, energy, and success.Â I couldnâ€™t imagine a better pair for blue and greenâ€™s calm, comforting presence than the passion and success of orange and red. Together, they seemed to makeÂ a dynamic duo, so I tried using those color pairs over the past yearâ€¦Out of our top 10 posts, 8Â of them have either blue or green as the main color. The remaining two blog posts have orange as their main color. Absolutely none of our top performing posts contain any otherÂ main colors! By understanding which colors performed better, we were able to helpÂ increase our page views byÂ 833.76%!You can do this, too!Simply follow the steps below to see which colors work best for your brand:While everyone has different colors that matchÂ their brand and audience demographics, itâ€™s essential to test out the waters and find the colors that work best for you! But when in doubtâ€¦ use blue or green.Now that you know your target image size and top-performing colors, itâ€™s time to decide what type of image toÂ use. While almost anything can be an imageâ€”screenshots, illustrations, photos, quotes, GIFsâ€”there are a few standout images youÂ can depend upon to receive the most engagement.Quotes come in all shapes and sizes. Facebook isnâ€™t alone!Hereâ€™s another example from Twitter:20 Ways To Be Creative When You Don't Feel Inspired https://t.co/JS5YcKZFoQ pic.twitter.com/hRaof4lPfVâ€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) January 16, 2016This tweet receivedÂ 2,107 impressions and 38 engagements because the quote had insight, intrigue, and direct application. Even in challenging situations, GIFs can bring a delight to those who would rather be frustrated.Hereâ€™s an example:Uh, oh. #facebookdown In the meantime, enjoy a cat gif! pic.twitter.com/34o2LYk61aâ€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) September 28, 2015By using a GIF and bringing a humorous moment to a normal circumstance, we receivedÂ 15,953 impressions and 381 engagements! You Can Now Pin To Pinterest With CoSchedule https://t.co/014yRye9xG pic.twitter.com/uo6Kenojn6â€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) March 8, 2016Just by turning a static image into a motion-filled GIF, the tweet receivedÂ 1,328 impressions, 77 views, and 15 engagements! Plus, this tweet isnâ€™t alone! When tweets contain GIFs, they get 166.6% more clickthroughs. GIFs allow motion to make your social posts stand out, get even more attention, and bring delight.What are some of your favorite GIFs?At this point, itâ€™s no secret that infographics are one of the most popular and highest shared content typesÂ in todayâ€™s digital world. Not only do they get shared more often, but theyâ€™re also 30 times more likely to be read than a purely textual article!If thatÂ wasnâ€™t good enough, infographics are also the perfect pair for one of the top-performing visual bookmarking site: Pinterest.Infographics get a lot of attention onÂ PinterestÂ because they tend to be longer in format, which fits Pinterestâ€™s 4:5 image ratio that receives 60% more Repins. Hereâ€™s an example of our top-performing pin:;Is it a surprise that it happens to be an infographic? I think not.YouÂ work really hard to find the perfect headline for your content. YouÂ search forÂ keywords, wordsÂ filled with emotion,Â then use the headline analyzer to find the precise, most-effective title. So why not take advantage of that in your social image?At CoSchedule, we reviewed some of our top-performing tweets, and found that they all included a title image.Â Our topÂ tweet in December received 2,280 impressions and 12 engagements, our top tweet in JanuaryÂ had 3,486Â impressions and 51Â engagements, and in FebruaryÂ our top tweet got a total of 5,419Â impressions and 79 engagements all with title graphics. Thatâ€™s an average of 3,727 impressions and 30Â engagements from using a title graphic within the tweet.December Example:Â Remember to put email signup opportunities at the end of your content. #blogging https://t.co/EMWHSNg0JD pic.twitter.com/kNfscXsTw1â€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) December 4, 2015JanuaryÂ Example:
This Is The Best Placement For Successful Social Media Buttons https://t.co/DeOXvDuirr pic.twitter.com/3uLQxx2py0â€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) January 25, 2016
February Example:How To Get More Followers With 21 Unique Ways That Will Boost Your Reach https://t.co/eRXrZgioYI pic.twitter.com/jEPwmLnXjuâ€” CoSchedule (@CoSchedule) February 8, 2016

As you can see, titles extend beyond the written context, and can certainly be effective within the graphic itself. Find the title of your blog, announcement, or event, and use that in the image to see the top performance.Social media images can take quite a few different forms, colors, and sizesâ€”but with this data, youâ€™ve found exactly what equation works best for each social network.If you happen to be in a rush or maybe youâ€™re just starting out, use aÂ 2:1 ratio for your image size, incorporate blue or green with a pop of orange or red in your color scheme, and stick to the four main image types: GIFs, quotes, titles, and infographics. Without much time at all, youâ€™ll be on your way to success!What colors, sizes, and image types have worked best for you? Share below!Click To Tweet

Thx!Great question, Christine! Itâ€™s soooo easy to save all these images and then later be left with a mess to dig through (and lets be honest, nobody wants that!). For CoSchedule we use this naming convention: Blog-AuthorName-Keyword-Title.png.So for example, this post was â€˜Blog-Ashton-SocialMediaImages-Twitter.png, Blog-Ashton-SocialMediaImages-Facebook.png, Blog-Ashton-SocialMediaImages-LinkedIn.pngâ€™ etc.This way, when I look back over time, I can search my files either by authorâ€™s name or by keyword. That image size looks good, and fits the 2:1 ratio as you mention. If you want to use the Photoshop Action included in the download, a 1500px by 645px is the magic number for your starting image. From there, itâ€™ll size everything else correctly for you with a click of a button!For title graphics, every brand has the freedom to be different, but speaking on behalf of what we do at CoSchedule, we have a style guide that includes 3 core typefaces with their primary usesâ€”one of them being titles and headlines. By using the same typefaces in certain use cases, it creates a nice consistency that our readers enjoy.Hope that helps!Great Ashton. From what Iâ€™ve seen, Twitterâ€™s finished size is 440 by 220px so I think anything that is a 2:1 ratio should work for it. Nice work!@ashtonwirrenga:disqus speaking of colors: do you recommend to use the same green and blue colors for every image or (as I think you do at Coschedule) to use different kinds of green and blue from image to image?Super helpful post! Thanks so muchNicole | The Professional Mom ProjectYouâ€™re very welcome, Nicole! Thanks for reading!this is a plethora of informationHey Shelley, thanks so much for reading! Happy to help!FANTASTIC post â€“ bookmarked forâ€¦forever!Wow, thanks so much!So much awesome infoâ€¦ but, Iâ€™m not understanding how the action is supposed to work. None of the steps says for which social media network it is sizing to and the saving options arenâ€™t working. Am I missing something or is there a tutorial somewhere?Hey Jenny, thanks for reading! The instructions for the Photoshop action are in the .txt file named â€˜ReadMeâ€™ that was included in the download folder. Basically, any image thatâ€™s 1500 by 645px will be automatically sized down for Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Google+! Youâ€™ll see which network each image is for based on the saved file name. Hope that helps!Â© 2016, Coschedule - Terms of Service, Privacy Policy",CoSchedule,2

column1: 2016-03-24,http://coschedule.com/blog/marketing-project-management-software/,Save Time With Marketing Project Management Software,"The free blog post headline analyzer will score your overall headline quality and rate its ability to result in social shares, increased traffic, and SEO value.The Convince and Convert team (C&C) get anywhere from 50â€“200 guest post submissions every week. They just know!Get your team involved early on.Â Folks will own itÂ if they have a hand in the planning process.Things to keep in mind when you plan aÂ brainstorming meeting:Next, create a one-sentence statement to help define the purpose of your meeting. This sentence will create a clear picture as to why and what needs to be accomplished.During the meeting:Create an environment that encourages ideas and minimizes groupthink.Â Not sure where to start?Once youâ€™ve got a list of all possible tasks in the workflow process, start prioritizing them.Tips for going through your list:Recommended Reading:Â How To Choose The Perfect Blog CategoriesAfter youâ€™ve cleaned up the list and defined the purpose of the project, itâ€™s time to implement a timeline with deadlines to accomplish your goal.In order to figure out your timeline:This is where over-communication comes in handyÂ because we all have our own definition of what â€œdoneâ€ means.Save your team hours of wasted time and miscommunication by clearly defining what complete means for each task in the process.Next, designate a specific person or role for each task.Again, over-communication and clarification areÂ crucial in the beginning. column1: 2016-04-04,http://coschedule.com/blog/seo-tips/,27 Important SEO Tips You Need To Know Now - CoSchedule,"The free blog post headline analyzer will score your overall headline quality and rate its ability to result in social shares, increased traffic, and SEO value.Search engine optimization often seemsÂ like magicÂ to newcomers.The elements of a strong SEO strategy often arenâ€™t obviousÂ to an untrained eye. However, once you understand howÂ the basics work, you can:Despite rumors to the contrary, SEO isnâ€™t dead. Furthermore, even the best content needs some help getting found.Thatâ€™s where these 27 SEO tips will come in handy. Whether youâ€™re a beginner just getting started, or an expert looking for a quick refresher, this post provides a basic understanding of the most essential elements necessary for SEO success. Plus, weâ€™ve also included an on-page SEO checklist to help youÂ nail every blog post you write.Click To Tweet

column12: Table of Contents:You may have heard rumblings that SEO is an outdated practice. You might have even heard that basic search engine optimization is completely unnecessary in 2016.However, this couldnâ€™t be further from the truth. In fact,Â SEO is as important as ever. Furthermore, if youâ€™re not paying attention, you mightÂ not be getting all the traffic you could be.Â While search engine algorithms and SEO best practices are constantly evolving, itâ€™s still important to know the basics and not rely on luck to get your content to rank.Thatâ€™s where the following tips come in hand.Keywords are essential toÂ any sound SEO campaign. Search engines need them to understand what your post is about. Users need them to help find answers to their questions. Your goal is to create great resourcesÂ that answers common search queries.The Google Adwords Keyword Planner is every marketerâ€™s trusted warhorse for keyword research. Itâ€™s useful for uncoveringÂ keyword search volumes and generating additional keyword ideas.Â Check out this video below to see how it works:We love this free keyword tool from SERPs.com. Itâ€™s fast, effective, and incredibly easy to use.Hereâ€™s how it works:Itâ€™s as simple as that.If you have a paid Moz subscription, then you know how useful their Keyword Difficulty tool can be. However, what if you canâ€™t afford a premium SEO software suite?Enter SEMRush.While they do offer paid plans, you can easily use their Keyword Difficulty tool with a free subscription:1. Â Sign up for a free SEMRush account.2. Find Keyword Difficulty in the left-hand navigation.3.Â EnterÂ keywords youâ€™d like to check (up to 10 at a time)Weâ€™ve covered how Googleâ€™s Keyword Planner is useful for gauging keyword search volumes.However, you can also use it to generate keyword ideas based on your competition:1. Start with a fresh search for keywords based on a website:2.Â Enter a competitorâ€™s domain or landing page URL to use as a basis for keyword ideas:3. You have now generated tons of keyword ideas based on what your competitor could potentially target. Consider going after these keywords before they do, or check to see if theyâ€™re already ranking on these terms.SEMRush is another useful tool for uncoveringÂ competitorâ€™s keywords.1.Â Log into your account and click on Organic Research:2.Â Enter a domain and see which keywords itâ€™s ranking for:Using this process, you might be able to find keywords you wouldnâ€™t have thought toÂ target.Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Meta tags are snippets of text that exist in your website or blogâ€™s code. According to Search Engine Watch:HTML meta tags are officially page data tags that lie between the open and closing head tags in the HTML code of a document.Â The text in these tags is not displayed, but parsable and tells the browsers (or other web services) specific information about the page. Simply, it â€œexplainsâ€ the page so a browser can understand it.There are two meta tagsÂ you need to customize for every post on your blog. They are the title tag and the meta description tag.The title tag tells users and search engines what your web page is about.Â Meanwhile, the meta description tag provides readers with more information about your page. Both are displayed in search engine result pages (SERPs).Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Here is what they look like in the search results:There are three essential elements (plus one thatâ€™s optional) to writing a quality title tag:Meta tags should give readers a reason to click your search result. Think of them as ad copy for your blog post.Here are a few important technical items to remember when writing meta descriptions:BONUS TIP: Want to see what your title tag and meta description will look like before publishing? Use a free online SERP preview tool. Here are three different options:A SERP preview tool can be useful for seeing how your search snippets will appear before publishing your blog post.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Youâ€™ve probably heard the cliche â€œcontent is king.â€Weâ€™ve heard this line repeated more times than weâ€™d like to count. However, the sentiment behind this phrase rings true. You canâ€™t have an SEO strategy withoutÂ quality content. Follow these tips to write copy thatâ€™s well-optimized for search engines without sounding spammy or mechanical.Itâ€™s important to make sure your primary keyword is included in several different places in your post. This is one of the most basic elements of on-page SEO.Longtail keywords are longer variations of your primary keyword.For example, if your primary keyword was â€œcontent marketing,â€ some longÂ tail variations might include:These are just a few hypothetical examples.Latent Semantic IndexingÂ refers to the way search engines look for relevant themes on web pages, rather than just keyword densities. According to long-time SEO expert Bruce Clay:In latent semantic indexing, Google sorts sites on the frequency of a variety of terms and key phrases linked together instead of on the frequency of a single term. Though your text content should include your main keyword or phrase, the content should never focus solely on that keyword or phrase. There is a possibility that Google may see the page as being over-optimized and penalties or a dip in rankings may result.In other words, use synonyms and phrasing variations of your primary keyword. Donâ€™t just repeat your primary keyword ad nauseam. This will look redundant and spammy both to readers and search engines alike.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Moz CEO Rand FishkinÂ does a great job of explaining how to use semantically connected keywords:Always write content with your audience in mind. If something sounds overly mechanical and over-optimized for search engines, readers will notice.This means you need to avoid keyword stuffing.Donâ€™t stick keywords everywhere possible in your post. Instead, spread them out naturally throughout your post. Odds are, youâ€™ll include long tail keywords naturally as you write anyway.Hereâ€™s an example of a well-written sentence including the keyword â€œburrito recipeâ€:â€œRead more to learn how to make this excellent burrito recipe at home.â€Hereâ€™s an example of what keyword stuffing might look like in this instance:â€œThis is the best burrito recipe for awesome bean burrito recipes on the Internet.â€One of these sentences reads clearly and includes the primary keyword in a useful way. The other sounds unnatural and over-optimized.Comprehensive blog posts should be as long as needed to thoroughly cover a topic.Studies show that blog posts withÂ at least 1,500 words rank best. Another study from Neil Patel ups that claim to 3,000 words.Â These studies tell us two things:1.Â Search engines want their users to have a great experience.That means that youâ€™ll need to help them find the right information fast.For this reason, search enginesÂ prefer to rank content that thoroughly answers a userâ€™s question about a topic. Ideally, they want your content to tell them everything they need to know without having to check another search result listing (which slows down the user and creates a weaker user experience).2. It takes a fair amountÂ of words to really cover most topics thoroughlyÂ (somewhere in the 1,500 t0 3,000 word range, or more).This doesnâ€™t mean you need toÂ pad your content with filler to hit a high word count. That wonâ€™t help you create useful content or rank highly in search engines.Â Do the following instead:SEO experts have been telling people to create unique content for years. However, they donâ€™t always follow up with what â€œunique contentâ€ really means.When it comes to content marketing and SEO, unique content:Here are some ways to ensure your content is unique:Using correct heading tags makes your posts easier to read. It also makes it easier for search engines to accurately interpret and index your content.You can find your heading controls in WordPress here:Search engines canâ€™t â€œlookâ€ at your images to determine their content. Instead, they use a handful of other data points to understand what your images are.File names are important element that search engines need to accurately interpret image content. Follow these guidelines:Hereâ€™s what a well-formatted image file name might look like:You get the point. This is something thatâ€™s often overlooked, but it can help you rank in image searches. It can also help support the overall SEO performance of your blog posts.You might notice that WordPress fills in image titles by default.However, there is some debate around how useful they are for SEO. After all, if youâ€™ve given your image a descriptive file name and alt text, users and search engines alike should have all the information they need to understand your image.Including title tags isnâ€™t likely to hurt your SEO. It wonâ€™t help much either, and it could cause your images to appear over-optimized (by trying to stuff too many keywords in your image data).Alt text essentially provides alternative information to describe an imageâ€™s content.You can easily edit image alt tags in WordPress here:

Alt text is important for two reasons:Bloggers often upload large images into WordPress, and then adjust the display size within the CMS.However, this slows down page load speed because it forces WordPress to resize the image as itâ€™s trying to load the page. Since page load speed is an important SEO factor, that can cause a problem.The solution is to upload images with the exact dimensions you want them to appear with. That way, your CMS wonâ€™t have to work as hard to load your images.For example, the column width of the CoSchedule blog is 770 pixels. Therefore, we upload our images at 770 pixels wide (or less).If you want to find the exactÂ column width of your own blog, try using this Page Ruler extension for Chrome. It makes it easy to measure pixels:Search engines use links to determine relationships between different pages and web sites. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important to earn backlinks from high-quality sites to improve your SEO. Itâ€™s also important to make sure relevant pages and posts on your own site are linked as well.However, going overboard with optimizing internal links can get you in trouble with search engines. Follow these two tips to make sure you donâ€™t overdo it with internal linking.This tip requires some explanation about what follow and no follow links are.Google doesnâ€™t want to see you creating garbage content just to get links. Readers donâ€™t either.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?To combat this, Google issued a warning to bloggers to make author box links no-follow. Even if your guest posts are legitimate and high-quality, making bio box links no-follow avoids creating the appearance of spamming (because search bots sometimes have difficulty telling the difference between whatâ€™s legitimate and whatâ€™s not).Anchor text refers to the highlighted words used to link to another page.Search engines use anchor text to help them understand relationships betweenÂ linked pages. For example, if your anchor text is â€œburrito recipes,â€ search engines can infer that the page youâ€™re linking to is probably related to making burritos. It can also understand that making burritos is relevant to the page where the linked text exists.Itâ€™s important to make sure your anchor text is not over-optimized. This is especially when linking internally to your own posts.Hereâ€™s why:However, you need to be careful not to use anchor text that is an exact match for the keyword the linked pageÂ is optimized for. For example, letâ€™s say you have one page targeting the keywordÂ â€œburrito recipesâ€ and another page targeting â€œburrito catering servicesâ€ (please bear with me and my burrito obsession here).If you were to place a link (or worse, multiple links) from your burrito recipes page to your catering page, using the exact-match anchor text â€œburrito catering services,â€ this would be considered SPAM.Thereâ€™s a good reason search engines consider over-optimized anchors to be spammy, too. The tactic has been over-abused over the years because itâ€™s an overly easy way to tell search engines, â€œHey, Iâ€™m trying really hard to get this page to rank for this keyword.â€Instead, follow these guidelines when selecting anchor text:1. Use a sentence fragment incorporating text that is relevant to the page being linked to, but is not an exact keyword match.2. Itâ€™s okay to use brand names or proper nouns as text anchors.Keep these two points in mind, and youâ€™llÂ have smooth sailing ahead for your internal linking efforts.WordPress has a number of unique SEO considerations. Follow these tips to make sureÂ your WordPress blog plays nice with search engines.If thereâ€™s only one WordPress plugin you use (aside from CoSchedule), make it Yoast. Itâ€™s packed full of powerful functionality for improving your SEO.Here are some things it can do:Once installed, you can find the Yoast control panel at the bottom of your post within your WordPress CMS.Download Yoast here. Then, watch the video below to learn how to use it in under 30 minutes:Mobile web traffic is gaining ground over desktop usage. Thatâ€™s why Google gives preference to mobile-optimized sites when calculating mobile search results.That means itâ€™s more important than ever to make sure your blog looks great on mobile devices.The easiest way to do this is to use a mobile-optimized WordPress theme. A quick Google search for mobile optimized WordPress themes should generate tons of different options to choose from.Search engines use keywords in URLs to help them determine what your pages are about.However, WordPress uses weird, non-optimal URLs by default which usually look something like this:www.RandomBlog.com/blog/?8973834What you want are URLs that look more like this:www.RandomBlog.com/blog/awesome-keywordThat keyword is going to make 100% more sense to search engines than a question mark followed by a random string of numbers.Watch this video to learn how to implement SEO-friendly permalinks:Broken links wonâ€™t necessarily lead to problems for your SEO. However, they do create a poor user experience (even if you have a really funny 404 page). That can hurt your overall SEO efforts indirectly by causing visitors to leave.Fortunately, broken links are easy to fix. The Broken Link Checker pluginÂ makes it easy to identify and resolve 404 errors.You can also use another useful tool called Screaming FrogÂ to tackle this task. Download it here, then follow their detailed step-by-step instructions on fixing broken links.Itâ€™s important to know whether your SEO initiatives are making a difference. By tracking the right metrics, the right way, you can make sure you know if youâ€™re on the right track. You can also more easily identify areas for opportunity.Google Analytics is one of the best tools for measuring the success of your SEO. If youâ€™re just getting started, consider importing the New Google Analytics User Starter Bundle from Google. Itâ€™s packed full of dashboards that are set up to monitor SEO performance (and a lot more) with minimal effort.Follow these steps to get started:1.Â Find the bundle in theÂ Google Analytics Solutions Gallery.2. Click Import.In two easy steps, you now have all the dashboards you need to measure your success.When it comes to SEO, marketers tend to focus on rankings.However, rankings are not a strong key performance indicator (KPI) on their own. This is partly because personalized search makes it difficult to accurately track rankings across all users. Itâ€™s also because rankings are a means to an end (driving traffic to your blog), rather than an end by themselves.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Instead, focus on traffic, conversion rates, and revenue (or leads generated, depending on which is more applicable to your situation). These metrics will tell you much more about your SEO success than rankings alone.SEO software subscriptions cost money. However, theyâ€™re worth it if you can afford them.These services allow you to do the following (and more):Here are some popular options to consider:Tools like Moz Pro feature tons of functionality to help manage your SEO efforts.SEO is a deep discipline. It covers a broad range of tactics, strategies, and best practices.For this reason, itâ€™s impossibleÂ to cover all there is to know in one post. In fact, if youâ€™re just starting out, it may take a while to digest everything this post alone. While weâ€™ve touched on the most basic elements most content marketers need to know, here are some other great resources to check out when youâ€™re ready.Resources For Further LearningMozâ€™s Beginnerâ€™s Guide To SEO:This comprehensive guide is broken up into ten chapters. It covers nearly everything youâ€™d ever need to know. Best of all, itâ€™s easy to follow and understand.The Art Of SEO:This book is intimidatingly thick, but fortunately, itâ€™s well worth your time. AsÂ the most authoritative tome on SEO available in print, it walks readers through everything from the basics, up to more advanced techniques. If youâ€™re ready to really take your SEO knowledge to the next level, start here.58 Resources To Help You Learn and Master SEO:This list from Kissmetrics includes articles breaking down nearly every aspect of SEO. If thereâ€™s something specific you want to know more about, you can probably find it here.Inbound.org:One of the best things about the content marketing and SEO communities is how open they are to sharing knowledge and welcoming newcomers. Inbound.org is an awesome place to ask questions and find answers to anything youâ€™d like to know.Do you have a favorite tip you want to share? Let us know in the comments below.Click To Tweet
Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?

column1: Just one question, why do I need to separate words in image file names with â€“ (dashes) and not with _ (underscores)?Thatâ€™s a good question. Dashes are easier for search engines to read through than underscores, and theyâ€™re what Google suggests using in their own image publishing guidelines. This video from ex-Googler Matt Cutts offers a more detailed explanation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AQcSFsQyct8ThanksHey Ben,I thoroughly enjoyed reading your post â€“ it was packed with useful tips!

I was a little surprised about the â€˜Image Title Tagâ€™ being left blank; Iâ€™d not heard about that. Why does WordPress have a slot for it if it can cause problems? Iâ€™ve always filled that in, often with the same as the Alt Text. Eek!! Is this info based on your experience or has Google mentioned this themselves?Thanks for a great post!

â€“ DavidGreat question, David. The main issue is that Google just doesnâ€™t pay much attention to image title tags, preferring to use image file names and alt tags as stronger ranking signals (title tags are more for users than search bots). The secondary issue is that if you have your keyword in the file name, alt tag, and title tag, thereâ€™s a small chance it could look like keyword stuffing if theyâ€™re all identical. This can be avoided by making your image title tag sufficiently different than your file name and alt tag (in my experience, WordPress duplicates the file name as the title tag by default). Iâ€™m not sure why this is the case, though, and Iâ€™d be curious to know as well.Googleâ€™s own advice is a little less clear. In their image publishing guidelines, they recommend making image title tags â€œdescriptive,â€ but they donâ€™t stress them as an important ranking factor (although they do suggest they help provide some context to what images are about): https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/114016?hl=enHowever, here Google says they look more closely at alt text, and suggest using title tags only if they provide value to users: https://webmasters.googleblog.com/2007/12/using-alt-attributes-smartly.htmlTitle tags appear as hover text over images for users in Firefox and Opera, so they do have a small amount of value that way. Since image title tags have little essential upside though, but do have a small amount of potential to make your images look spammy if theyâ€™re not implemented correctly, I personally recommend leaving that field blank. Thatâ€™s not necessarily a consensus opinion though, and others might suggest otherwise (and thatâ€™s okay).TL;DR â€“  as long as youâ€™re careful to differentiate your title tags from your alt text and file names, you shouldnâ€™t have anything to worry about. Iâ€™m just personally more comfortable excluding non-essential image elements to avoid keyword stuffing (especially when thereâ€™s not much clear benefit otherwise).Hope this helps!Also, to avoid possible confusion, when I say â€œtitle tagsâ€ in this context, Iâ€™m referring specifically to â€œimage title tagsâ€.Sure, understood!Thanks Ben!
Google never make it clear do they? :-)

Iâ€™ll take note to keep this clear of different from henceforth.Well done! Relieved to have known most of the things on the list, but am still bookmarking to try some of the recommended tools. We mean in-depth posts that thoroughlyÂ cover your given topic. The kind of stuff that establishes you as a topical authority and brings in non-stop traffic.Everyone wants to create awesome evergreen content that keeps visitors coming back. The problem is that it isnâ€™t easy to writeÂ exhaustively detailed andÂ well-researched blog posts. Itâ€™s even less easy when you donâ€™t have much time to write. However, when it comes to content creation, extra effort is often rewarded.You need to nail down an effective blog writing process. Then, you need to apply that process every time you write a post.If youâ€™re ready to take your blogging and content writing skills to the next level, this post is for you. Weâ€™ll walk through the entire process from end to end, from generating an idea to editing the final piece.Â By the time youâ€™re done, youâ€™ll be prepared to write highly authoritative posts that leave no stone unturned and no detail unaccounted for.Table of ContentsClick To Tweet

column12: Organization isnâ€™t necessarily the fun part of writing. However, getting organized now will help you get more done later. Here are a handful of tips and ideas to help you make the most of your limited working time.Let us quickly state the obvious: different writers work differently.This extends not only to how we work, but where we work best. If youâ€™re working in an office environment, you may or may not have flexibility on where you get your writing done. However, if you have the option, itâ€™s worth working in different types of spaces to find what suits you. Whether you prefer busyÂ coffee shops or a quiet corner space in your office, being in the right environment canÂ make a positive impact on your productivity.You probablyÂ use a wide variety of tools in your blog writing workflow. However, there are a few ways to make sure you always have quick access to what you need.If you need help avoiding digital distractions, consider using aÂ minimalist word processor. Each of these options can be used to block out everything on your screen, except the words youâ€™re hammering out:Here is a screenshot of Focus Writer in action. It features several different selectable background themes.Before you can write your blog post, you need toÂ know what youâ€™ll write about. This entails:Letâ€™s get started.It isnâ€™t easy to consistently come up with content ideas your readers will love.Â However, here are some guidelines to follow to help you come up with more ideas, more quickly.This ever-trusty standbyÂ needs to be in every content marketerâ€™s arsenal. Hereâ€™s to leverage it to find awesome post ideas:1.)Â Create an account. Even if youâ€™re not paying to run any ads, you do have an Adwords account, right?2.) Select the first option pictured below:3.) Enter a keyword or topic:4.) Youâ€™ll now have two tabs full of ideas. One is for ad groups, and the other is for keywords.5.) Weâ€™ve now taken one broad topic and spun off 800 possible keywords.Brainstorming with a team is one of the most efficient ways to generate blog post ideas. Plus, it doesnâ€™t have to take too long, either. Follow this process to generate tons of ideas quick:By the time youâ€™re done, youâ€™ll have a mountain of ideas to work with. Plus, by getting multiple team members involved, youâ€™ll likely come up with more diverse and innovative ideas.Running an online survey or poll is an excellent way to do audience research and gather original data. Survey Monkey and Polldaddy are both easy to use tools just for this purpose (we use Polldaddy here at CoSchedule).Follow these steps to run a survey:Follow these steps to make use of your data:By the time youâ€™re done, youâ€™ll have a solid understanding of what your readers want. Youâ€™ll also have a good idea of who your real audience is (and weâ€™ll touch on that more later).Once you have a strong list of content ideas, itâ€™s time to validate which are best. This process will help you zero in on the blog topics you absolutely have to write (and the ones you shouldnâ€™t).Use the Google Adwords Keyword Planner to checkÂ how often keywords related to your idea get searched. If you used this in the previous step, you should already have this data.Google Trends is a handy tool for seeing how often a topic is getting written about. Hereâ€™s how it works:1.) Enter aÂ topic you might want to write about:2.) If you see increased interest in your idea, then you know you might be onto something.This is probably the simplest and most direct way to get feedback for your idea.Â If you get a strong level of engagement, youâ€™ll know your audience is interested in your topic. You can also incorporate their questions and comments into your post.To create a post thatâ€™s both comprehensive and useful, you need to go in-depth on a narrowly defined subject. This means pinpointingÂ one specific idea with laser-like focus.For example, letâ€™s say you manageÂ a blog aboutÂ carÂ maintenance. This could be a personal blog, or you might manage this blog for a company in the automotive industry. In this instance, something like â€œHow To Take Care Of Your Carâ€ would be an extremely broad topic you could cover.However, a better question to ask might be, â€œWhat specifically could I write about when it comes to car maintenance?â€Â A hypothetical short list might look like this:Follow these steps to refine your idea into something super-specific people want to read:Hereâ€™s a quick example from another post on the CoSchedule blogÂ that does a great job of focusing on a very specific area within a broader topic:Immediately, you know exactly what this post is about. You also know which problem this post will help you solve, or what itâ€™ll help you know more about.Â Thatâ€™s the goal you want to achieve.Once you have your idea solidified, itâ€™s time to go deep on your research.In most cases, you can find what you need with nothing more than a search engine (most likely Google or Bing). However, if you really want to take your research to the next level, it might be worth going beyond the Google search box.Remember, the Internet is a big place. Youâ€™ve got a lot of resources at your fingertips, and depending on what your blog is about, there may be otherÂ useful research tools out there for you.Here are some basic things to remember when doing any kind of serious online research:If youâ€™re familiar with advanced Google search operators, then you know how helpful they can be.Theyâ€™re best understood as the punctuation you include in aÂ search term to help the search engine understand exactly what youâ€™re looking for.Â For example, they can be used to search for results only within a single site, or for sites that only contain certain terms.Hereâ€™s a short list of useful search operators to help you do detailedÂ searches on Google:Search Specific Site: site:[URL] [Search Term]

column1: Search Related Sites: related:[URL] [Search Term]
Search Multiple Words: [Search Term 1] OR [Search Term 2]
Get Info About A Website: info:[URL]

For most bloggers and marketers, research starts and ends with Google. In most cases, that might be all you need.However, if you really want to dig deep,Â itâ€™s time to go beyond the worldâ€™s most popular search engine. Consider startingÂ with some of these options.Wolfram Alpha isÂ an extremely powerful research tool. Itâ€™s like an encyclopedia, calculator, and search engine all rolled into one. To use their own words, itÂ works â€œby doingÂ dynamic computations based on a vast collection of built-in data, algorithms, and methods.â€ In plain English, itâ€™s useful for calculating and comparing differences between different topics and pieces of data.Here are some things Wolfram AlphaÂ can do:This is just a short list of possibilities. If you really want to leverage what Wolfram Alpha can do, start with their tour of the basics. This video from founder Stephen Wolfram himself offers a good introduction:There are tons of useful archives and databases out there, especially if your blog has an academic focus. Consider the following:These types of resources may or may not be useful, depending on what youâ€™re writing about. The idea is simply to think beyond obvious sources to find information that hasnâ€™t already been repeated a million times elsewhere on the web.Youâ€™ve got to plan to succeed. Thatâ€™s where writing your blog outline comes in.Writing without an outline is like driving without a map (or to use a more modern metaphor, your smartphone). Youâ€™ll be fine if youâ€™re going a short distance.If youâ€™re going to be covering a lot of ground, however,Â you need to know where youâ€™re going. Otherwise, youâ€™re likely to get lost, waste time, and probably yell.In most cases, this simply entails listing your introduction, and then your subsequent section headings. Each heading should represent a main point you want to elaborate on. Hereâ€™s what a simple outline structure could look like:It doesnâ€™t need to complicated. It just needs to be quick to put together and effective in guiding your writing flow.Once youâ€™ve established each section of your post, itâ€™s time to drill down even deeper into your sub-points. Identify which points youâ€™ll cover, underneath each section heading.Now, your outline might look something like this (this is an actual outline I wrote for this post):Your outline doesnâ€™t need to be polished. Nor does each section heading need to be final. It just needs to provide a guide for you to follow as you write, and it can be changed as you progress.If speed is of the essence, and you already have strong knowledge of your topic, thenÂ consider skipping the outlining phase. You might be able to cut your research a bit short too, in that case.However, youâ€™ll likely find that sketching out a quick outline will save time in the long run. Furthermore, while avoiding outlines may allow for creative freedom when writing fiction, blog posts (at least the kinds of blog posts weâ€™re talking about right now) need to be focused.Youâ€™ve already done a lot of work, and you havenâ€™t even started to write your post yet. However, everything youâ€™ve done up until now will make the rest of your blog writing processÂ much easier.Write at least 20 to 30 different headline options. Some of them will be junk. Try to narrow it down to just one youâ€™ll use. You might also choose a few alternate headlines to test in social media posts.Here are some more quick tips for writing headlines:Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?First impressions matter.A strong blog post introduction has the power to hook a reader for the long haul. However, a poor intro can lead to a high bounce rate and send your traffic away.Hereâ€™s how to write an intro that sticks.Consider starting with an interesting fact.Â Things that are true but sound counterintuitive or difficult to believe are good.Another option is to start with your ending. This can help build suspense and make your reader curious to know how youâ€™ll reach your shocking conclusion.If appropriate, add a personal touch with a real-life anecdote. Start by telling a short story about an experience youâ€™ve had. Then, tie it into the premise of your post.Ask a question. This works well with how-to posts. Start with a question you know your audience wants to know about. Then, explain how youâ€™ll answer it.Not literally. We mean start with a cliffhanger. Build suspense, then stop right when youâ€™re about to explain what happened. Then, in the body of your post, work your way back to the beginning.Controversial posts can get you a lot of attention. However, you need to get your tone right straight away. The goal is to catch your audienceâ€™s attention with something they might disagree with. Then, gently lead the toward what you think is a better conclusion. Stand behind your convictions, but be careful not to be condescending, insulting, or unnecessarily abrasive.Ideally, your introduction should have set the stage for your body content to shine.FollowÂ your outline to ensure your posts follows a logical flow from start to finish.Feel free to make changes, but if you frequently find yourself deviating from your outline, it could be your idea needs a little more polish before itâ€™s ready.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Paragraphs in a blog post should be brief and to the point.Where appropriate, use single sentences to add punch behind statements (see above). Keep paragraphs down to two or three sentences for crispness and clarity (and avoid more than five at the most).This will keep your writing easy to read and skim through.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Give each section a descriptive heading.This is a good time to take the headings fromÂ your outline and turn them into something more attention-grabbing.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Here are some tips for writing sub-headings:Beneath each heading, you should have several sub-points that support the sectionâ€™s theme or idea.Take each bullet point you put beneath each heading in your outline. Then, add a few paragraphs on each one in the appropriate section. If you get on a roll and uncover more relevant information, add it into your post.Summary: Letâ€™s pull this all together to ensure youâ€™re equipped to write awesome body content for your blog post.This simple yet effective process will ensure your post follows a logical structure.Make sure your section headings follow a logical hierarchy by using proper heading tags. Use only one H1 tag per page (WordPress generally makes post headlines and H1, or â€œHeading 1â€).Then, make each sub-heading an H2, and subsequent sub-headings beneath those with H3, H4, H5, and H6 tags.In WordPress, use the dropdown menu under â€œParagraphâ€ to format your headings.Itâ€™s importantÂ links to other posts related to your topic.Links help readers find more information about your topic, help show where youâ€™re finding your information, and increase the odds other sites will link back to you (and send traffic your way).[Tweet â€œAre you linking to other content inside of your posts? #bloggingâ€ ]Links also help search engines determine what your post is about by drawing associations between linked content.Here are a few additional points to remember about links:Remember the keyword research we did earlier? Make sure youâ€™re including your primary keyword (along with other variations of that keyword phrase) throughout your blog post.Donâ€™t go overboard and stick keywords wherever possible. Instead, just make sure theyâ€™re present. This will help send a stronger signal to search engines to help your post rank in organic search.A good conclusion should tie your blog post together.At the most basic level, your conclusion should do the following:Thatâ€™s it. However, if you want to make your conclusion more helpful, consider taking these steps:Recommended Reading:Â How To Write A Blog Post: Your 5-Point Checklist To Rock A Perfect PostHere are some tips to add value to your blog writing process.If your goal is to write a comprehensive blog post, thenÂ the best length is however long it takes to say everything you need to about your topic. While studies show posts around 1,500 words rank best in search engines, your post might be dramatically longer than that if youâ€™re really going all-in on going in-depth. On the flip side, it could be shorter too, depending on how long it takes to exhaust your topic.Forget words counts. Focus on being thorough instead.If you tell readers to do something, but donâ€™t follow through on instructing them how to do it, they might leave your blog feeling frustrated. This a common and self-defeating trap for how-to blogs.Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s important to give your reader all the information they need to perform a given task, or develop a complete understanding of your topic.Here are a few tips to keep in mind if you write how-to content:Are you simply rehashing other peopleâ€™s content? If so, step back and think what you canÂ do differently than your competition.Take a look at some other posts on your topic and ask yourself these questions:Once youâ€™ve answered these questions, youâ€™ll have a clear picture ofÂ how to make your blog post unique.Write what you really believe. Donâ€™t put anything out there you donâ€™t think you or your company can stand behind. Youâ€™ll be more confident about what you write.Authenticity isnâ€™t something you can fake and itâ€™s not something you can leverage for status.Â All it takes is writing what you believe to be true, and being willing to defend it in the court of public opinion.Thatâ€™s it.Surly Brewing, an excellent craft brewery in Minneapolis, follows the philosophy that â€œbeer for everyone is beer for no one.â€ They know who their customers are, andÂ they donâ€™t try to make anyone else happy. As a result, theyâ€™re one of the most well-respected breweries in the Twin Cities.Marketers and bloggers can follow a similar approach to become a real topical authority.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Follow these guidelines:Your title tag and meta description are what appear in search engine results. Theyâ€™re the first thing people will see before visiting your post through a search.Hereâ€™s how to write strong title tags and meta descriptions:Itâ€™s hard to read long blog postsÂ with nothing but walls of text. They also look â€¦ well, pretty boring.While this is a post about the writing process for blog posts, letâ€™s touch on a few points about graphics and images.If you work with a designer, this is the point in the process where theyâ€™ll workÂ their magic. Here are some tips to make this process easier:However, if youâ€™re working alone and donâ€™t have design skills, youâ€™re not out of luck. Try some of these ideas:You now have no excuses for not including some visual content in your posts.Good writing is often the product of good editing. Itâ€™s an essential element of any blog writing process.Your first (or even second or third drafts) arenâ€™t always going to be golden right away. Thatâ€™s assuming you even have time to write multiple drafts.Itâ€™s important, however, to ensure that everything you writeÂ isÂ looked over before itâ€™s published. While itâ€™s always possible to edit mistakes or patch up omissions later (thanks to the Internet),Â itâ€™s better to get things right the first time. If you want to be seen as an authority, then your work needs to be polished and presentable.Notice we said â€œpolishedâ€ and â€œpresentable.â€ We didnâ€™t say â€œperfect.â€Thatâ€™s because chasing perfection is an unattainable goal. There are always going to be things you want to changeÂ or things you think you could have done better. Use those moments of reflection as learning opportunities. Then, improve the next post you work on. Thatâ€™s how you get better while still getting things done.If you have the benefit of working with an editor, consider yourself fortunate. Having someone on your team who can help elevate your standards for quality is extremely valuable for creating top-notch content.If youâ€™re writing your post for another blog as a freelancer or guest blogger, then knowing how to work with an editor will be extra crucial to your success.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Here are some tips to get the most from your writer-editor relationship:If you donâ€™t have an editor, donâ€™t worry.Â There are plenty of ways to edit your own work.Â Even if you do have an editor on your team, you should still know how to self-edit too.Follow these tips:Click To Tweet
Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Congratulations on making it to the end of this post!Weâ€™ve covered a lot of ground. Hereâ€™s a brief recap:Hereâ€™s one last takeaway weâ€™ll leave you with: writing processes and routines are as diverse as writers themselves.Haruki Murakami gets up at 4 am every day to write. Kurt Vonnegut swam to build the mental and physical endurance to write daily. Khaled Hosseini never writes an outline. You can bet that every writer, blogger, and content marketing thought leader you admire has some similar creative quirks.The point is that everyone has their own approach to their work. That includes you.This post is a framework for creating above-average blog posts; the kinds of posts that will establish you as an authority with the most comprehensive content anywhere in your niche.Â Ultimately though, youâ€™ll have to determine what works best for yourself.Â Feel free to change up the order of the steps in this post and create your own blog writing process. You can omit the parts that donâ€™t fit your needs, and tweak the parts that do.Now go out there andÂ share your expertise with the world!Click To Tweet

column1: Alright, for those of you whoâ€™d like to try this the more manual way, read on!Find Your Best Time To Post:After digging around the Internet a bit and analyzing our own data here at CoSchedule, IÂ compiled some research from within the past year and more recently, breaking it up into more palatable chunks of information. Iâ€™ll be referencing several sources in this blog post, including:In addition, these are a few bonus sources that may be slightly older than aÂ year:Letâ€™s get to it.Did you know that Arizona doesnâ€™t practice daylight savings time?Itâ€™s timing nuancesÂ like these that make finding the perfect times to post even harder.Â Before weÂ delve into the best times to post on social media, letâ€™sÂ take a look at the best time zones.50% of the U.S. population is in the Eastern Time Zone, and the Eastern and Central combined represent almost 80% of the U.S. population.In theory, the Eastern or Central timezone would be the best time to base off for a United States audience to reach the most people through your social media shares.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?For those of you who have audiences outside the United States,Â demographic research like this is simple enough with Google Analytics to understandÂ whereÂ your own audience is, giving you theÂ opportunity to target their time zones accordingly.There are also a few toolsÂ to help you find when your own audience is online and using the social networks youâ€™re concentrating onâ€”which helps you understand the best times to share based in your local time zone. Engagement is about 3.5% lower on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. And people seem to be happier on Friday (small wonder), so funny or upbeat content will fit right in to that â€œhappiness index.â€According to Patel, early afternoon is the optimal time to post on Facebook. 1 p.m. will get you the most shares, while 3 p.m. will get you the most clicks. Anytime between 9 a.m.â€“7 p.m. will always be better than content shared outside of that window.Elle & Co.:Â The best days to publish on Facebook areÂ Saturday and Sunday with the peak times atÂ 1 p.m. on those days. These posts get 32% more engagement than workweek posts.Â According to Elle &Â Co, the best time to post on Facebook is between 1â€“3 p.m.SurePayroll:Â Wednesday at 3 p.m. isÂ the best day to post on Facebook. But on average, 1â€“4 p.m. getÂ the highest clickthroughs. Monday and Wednesday getÂ the lowest engagement rates. Generally speaking, the best time to post on Facebook is between 1â€“3 p.m. and more broadly 9 a.m.â€“7 p.m. In addition, Facebook use spikes by 10% on Fridays.Kissmetrics:Â The best day to share on Facebook is Saturday, and shares tend to spike around noon and a little after 7 p.m. The best time to postÂ on Facebook isÂ noon.Buffer: Engagement rates are 18% higher on Thursdays and Fridays. column12: While your Pins are likely some of the first things potential followers see from your brand, Neil Patel notes itâ€™s super important to optimize your Pinterest profile to help you get more followers.This is likely due to the halo effect, which is the psychology behind first impressions and physical attractivenessâ€”something super important for the visual audience who loves Pinterest. In its most essential form, the halo effectÂ suggests that when people have a positive experience with you, theyâ€™re more likely to expect positive experiences in the future.Whoa! So if you make a good first impression, doesnâ€™t it make sense thatÂ you could get moreÂ followers because theyâ€™ll expect favorable outcomes in the future?So filling out your profile helps potential followers see youâ€™re not a fly-by-night Pinner while giving you the chance to share information about your blog, brand, and your other social networks.Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?While there are a lot of different fields to look into while fleshing out your Pinterest profile, here are the ones that will make a difference for getting more followers. Go to Settings to get started:Start with your Business Account BasicsÂ and slideÂ the Search privacy button to No.Â This way, Pinterest will allow search engines to crawl the content you Pin which could helpÂ you get more visibility in image searches with popular search engines like Google.Help Pinners find your content through search engines by changing your Search privacy setting to No.Then, in the Profile area, fill in your Business Name and Location.The Website field is one of the most important things Pinterest uses to verify your site, which will boost your credibility via the halo effect.You can also connect your other social networks directly into Pinterest.Â Mitt Ray, a Pinterest expert, took to Social Media Examiner to explain that this simple practice can â€œattract your Facebook and Twitter friends and followers to your Pinterest account.â€Simply signÂ in to your companyâ€™s Twitter handle. Then slide the Log in button to Yes. You can also connect to Facebook and Google+, but since those accounts are typically associated with a single person and not a business page, your Pinterest followers will be directed to your personal profiles.Connect your social profiles like your companyâ€™s Twitter handle to your Pinterest account.When you connect your social profiles, youâ€™ll get the added bonus of having them appear in your Pinterest profile, which is a great way to offer your Pinterest followers the opportunity to follow you on other networks, too.When you connect your Twitter handle (or Facebook and Google+ profiles), the icon will show up in your Pinterest profile to help you get more followers.NicoleÂ suggestsÂ havingÂ Pin it and follow prompts on your site to help convert the traffic you get into Pinners and followers.For example, Social Media Examiner uses the Pinterest follow prompt on their blog:Social Media Examiner uses the Pinterest follower button to convert blog visitors into Pinterest followers.And when you click on that button, an appealing window opens from Pinterest to help you convert yourÂ visitors into Pinterest followers:This is what your followers will see when you add the Pinterest follow button to your blog.Getting that follow buttonâ€”and the Pin It buttonâ€”is easy.Â When youâ€™re on your home page, click the gear icon and select Make a widget.Navigate to your Pinterest home page, then select the gear icon to make a follow widget.Then, in the popup, click Learn More.Click Learn More in the widget popup.Now you can create Pin It buttons for specific blog posts and also grabÂ a follow button you can embed in your theme.Create a follow button by entering in your Pinterest URL and embedding the code on your blog.Recommended Reading:This idea is an extension of what you just learned about the Pin It and follow buttonsÂ but relates much more directly to your blog posts.Pinterest now makes it easy to embed Pins and board previews right into your posts to help you get more followers from your blog visitors. Follow the same instructions from the prior step, and embed your Pinterest content like this:You should probably hit that follow button. Come on, you know you want to! ;)When we recently embedded a board like that into aÂ blog post, weÂ received a 640% boost in Pinterest followers that week.Some of your followers on other social networks may also like to follow you on Pinterest. It is definitely some peopleâ€™s preferred discover tool, as Nicole pointed out to me.And it turns out, Pinterest is smart enough to help you shareÂ your Pins and boards on your other social networks easily.Share your Pins to followers on other networks to encourage them to follow you on Pinterest.You can use that functionality to share your Pins with your TwitterÂ and Facebook followers to encourage them to follow you on Pinterest, too.Advertising isnâ€™t very effective because it talks to your audience, not with your audience.Communication is different than mass marketing because it is a real conversation between people and isnâ€™t one-sided.Â Thatâ€™s howÂ Pinners demand participation.Â And since thatâ€™s the case, itâ€™s a great lesson to keep in mind as you try to get moreÂ followers on Pinterest.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Nicole says:Donâ€™t be spammy. Pin at least 50/50 ratio of other content to your own. Treat Pinterest like its own entity, so get creative and CURATE.And that says a lot. Pinterest is an information discovery engine: Like a social site fusedÂ with a search engine. Pinterest feedsÂ on curation, and Pinners demand conformity to the culture for its participants.Still other Pinterest experts suggest Repinning even more contentÂ by following the Pareto principle of 80% Repins to 20% of your own original Pins.Regardless of your approach, here are the major reasons why Repinning will help you get more followers:As Aaron LeeÂ explains, â€œFollowing 5 to 10 people a day can make a huge difference compared to waiting for people to follow you.â€That makes sense, especially since you know PinterestÂ relies on participationâ€”and especially at first, you might have to make the first move to grow your following.Find Pinners to follow who have already shared your content by using this query: https://www.pinterest.com/source/YourDomain.com/. These Pinners would all make for great folks for CoSchedule to follow on Pinterest.Just click through to see those Pinnersâ€™ profiles and follow them.Nicole says:Make sure that you trust the source youâ€™re Pinning from. If itâ€™s spammy or not legit, you can be flagged as spam and land in Pinterest jail.Â So watch who you follow because spammers are rampant there, and only Repin from trusted sources.So how can you tell if a potential person youâ€™d like to follow isnâ€™t that great? Spam accounts might look a little like this where they share the same things over and over:You can learn a lot from Pinterest AnalyticsÂ including:The Activity tab in your Pinterest Analytics is probably the best place to start to find new potential followers. Simply scroll through to find the Pinners who gave you your top Pin impressions, and the boards that were most popular for your content.Pinterest Analytics can help you find popular boards from Pinners who share your content, which can help you find new followers.With that information, you can find the Pinners who created those boardsâ€”and those whoÂ followÂ themâ€”to start building your community.You can learn a lot from the Pinners who follow the popular boards that share your content.Everyone seems to have their favorite social networks, so why not reach out to your existing friends to see if theyâ€™d also like to connect with you on Pinterest? It turns out, Pinterest thought that was a pretty good idea and created a Find Friends feature right in the tool itself.Since youâ€™ve already connected your other social profiles like Twitter, Facebook, and Google+ into Pinterest, just navigate from your Pinterest profile to the Find Friends page.Navigate to the Find Friends feature from your Pinterest profile.From here, you can follow the people you already know from your other networks. Mitt Ray elaborates on this tacticÂ on Social Media Examiner, â€œAs you follow people you already have relationships with, theyâ€™ll be very likely to follow you back.â€Use Pinterestâ€™s Find Friends feature to follow people who already know, like, and trust you. That will encourage them to follow you on Pinterest.When content marketer Matthew Barby decided to start a food blog from absolutely nothing, he wrote about his experience getting his initial followers. One tactic that worked for himÂ involved researching his top competition and following the boards of his competitorsâ€™ followers.Matthew walks through those steps:This process, combined with solid content strategy, helped Matthew get an initial 515 Pinterest followers for a very competitive niche. The best part is that you can follow his advice and experience similar results.Hereâ€™s another Pinterest tipÂ from Nicole:Get into GREAT group boards, but donâ€™t go crazy with Pinning.Â When people follow those boards, they see your content, which could influence more shares. You want to find group boards thatÂ have high followersÂ andÂ relatively low contributors.When you join a group board, you will instantly have access to more followersâ€”to every Pinner who already follows that group board. Seems like great advice, so how can you find group boards that are right for you to contribute to?Start with PinGroupie. Itâ€™s a database site dedicated to helping Pinners find group boards. You can sort tons of boards by category, then number ofÂ followers to narrow the group boards to that of your niche that haveÂ a larger following with fewer contributors.PinGroupie will help you find group boards to grow your following on Pinterest.Group boards are especially helpful for getting more followers because when a Pinner choosesÂ to â€œFollow allâ€ of the boards from the creator, they also subscribe to receiving Pins from you through that group board.While existing group boards are a greatÂ way to tap into the leg work someone else has done to grow their Pinterest following, you can start a group board yourself and invite Pinners you already respect to join you.Just create a new board by hitting the + Create a board button, then invite other Pinners to contribute toÂ your board.Creating a new group board will help you tap into the followers your friends already have.Now, most group boards have ground rules and structure. A good place to start is by building the board out with a following using all of the advice youâ€™ve learned from this post, define your rules for participation, then invite others to join you once they can see the benefits of Pinning with you are worth it.Here are a few things to consider as you come up with your group board contribution guidelines:Write your guidelines up briefly, then add a note into your board description on how people can contact you to join.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Letâ€™s start this off by acknowledging that Pinterest is a bit wary of contests in general because marketers have abused them in the past. To run a successful contest and not end up in â€œPinterest Jailâ€ as Nicole calls it, follow their acceptable use policy:If youâ€™re thinking of hosting a Pinterest contest, know the rules first.While that sounds like a lot of things that you shouldnâ€™t do, that leaves you with a few creative ways that focus on real engagement (which is, after all, what your potential followersÂ really like anyway):However,Â a contest like this can help you increase your engagement and build a community that will inevitably turn participants into followers.You can start with Popular Pins, a category that Pinterest createsÂ with Pins that get a lot of engagement. Find a couple that you have experience with, and comment on them to share your perspective.As Mitt Ray notes, youâ€™re looking for more than easy comments like â€œNice Pin.â€ Provide your take on the Pin, additional advice itâ€™s missing, or takeaways youâ€™ve learned on that topic. Mitt says that this tactic can help you increase your visibilityâ€”and the potential of earning new followersâ€”because youâ€™re commenting on the most popular content on Pinterest.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?While that sounds smart, another very targeted way to reach more people is to comment on Pins from those whoâ€™ve already shared your content. Build trust with people who already know who you are by showing them the real personality behind your blog or brand.Hereâ€™s a reminder on how to find those folks: CheckÂ your Pinterest Analytics domain tab orÂ searchÂ this query for your domain:Â https://www.pinterest.com/source/YourDomain.com/.Consider mentions an extension of commenting and Repinning.Mention Pinners to spark a conversation.You can use mentions inÂ Pin descriptions and in comments, which â€œcan be a great way to attract their attention and get them to follow you.â€An easy tactic is to ask someone a question via a mention to spark up a conversation. The more interaction, the more likely theyâ€™ll be to follow you.Remember when you read that Pinterest is a fusion between social and search engines? That applies into the namesÂ and descriptions you use in your boards to helpÂ potential followers find your Pins.Rebekah Radice suggests that Pinterest boards should be direct, descriptive, andÂ personal to help you get more followers. And a few of the defining elements that make good boards stand out to new followers are solid coverÂ images, keyword rich names and descriptions, and a niche focus.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Letâ€™s explore each of those areas to help you get more followers by optimizing your boards:iFabbo, a resource for fashion bloggers, knows a thing or two about catching peopleâ€™s attention.They offer some simple advice for choosing your coverÂ images to make your boards stand out:You can create an image specifically for your board cover following those guidelines. First, Pin the image youâ€™d like as your cover. ThenÂ go to your Pinterest profile, hit Edit on your board, then on Cover, hit the Change button. You can choose any Pin youâ€™d like as your cover image.Your blog likely has a content core: The magical place where youÂ strategize what you want to say with what your audience wants to know. The process looks a little like this:Use the words your audience uses to describe that niche in your board descriptions.When you defined your target niche, you likely also found several sub-topics that you could cover. Use those topics in your board names to help Pinners find your content.Some kinds of content perform significantly better than others on Pinterest.Â So it makes sense, then, to use the experience from others to improve your own Pins:Nicole explains the art behind designing images and graphics for Pinterest:Make sure you are using vertical collage-type Pins, which perform much better on average than regular verticals because they take up more space on a userâ€™s screen.Â And always, always, always consider how it looks on mobile. Small and ugly text on photos can end up being totally unreadable on a mobile device.Â And a lotÂ of people are mobile pinning.And, of course, Nicole is right. 75% of Pinterestâ€™s users rock Pinterest on their mobile devices. That means if you donâ€™t consider mobile in your design, youâ€™re neglecting how three-fourths of your followers prefer to experience your content.Youâ€™ve alreadyÂ found keywords for your blog postsÂ that youâ€™re Pinning. Use those same keywords in your Pin descriptions to help potential followers find your content.Target keywords in your Pin descriptions to help potential followers find your content.Pinners are more active on certain days and times than others.Â When we analyzed 10 studies to find the best times to post on social media, the data told us:Thatâ€™s the sweeping general answer. You can Pin a lot every day, so what are really the best times when your audience is using Pinterest? After all, you are probably trying to attract new followers that are similar to your existing fans, so sharing at the peak times when theyâ€™re online could help you get more followers.So grab this Google Analytics custom reportÂ to find the best dayÂ to Pin based on your own audience (the report is also available in your kit that complements this post). When you use the report, youâ€™ll see a list ofÂ networks. Click through on Pinterest.Choose Pinterest from the list in your Google Analytics custom report to see the best day when you get traffic from Pinterest.Now youâ€™ll see theÂ list of daysÂ of the week when you typically get the most traffic from Pinterest.These are the days of the week when you get the most traffic from Pinterest. So these are the days when your followers are most active.You can drill in even further to find the specific best time to Pin to Pinterest on any day of the week.This is the best time of day to get traffic from Pinterest specifically for the day of the week you just selected.Or use this second Google Analytics custom reportÂ if youâ€™re looking for a bit more general information just on the best time to Pin when you typically get the most trafficâ€”omitting days (this report is alsoÂ in your kit).Just like the other report, click through on Pinterest and youâ€™ll see the times when you typically get the most traffic. 0 is midnight and 23 is 11 p.m.The Google Analytics custom report shows the times when you get the most traffic from Pinterest. Use this to gauge when your followers are most active and schedule your Pins accordingly.How many times to Pin a day? Itâ€™s a good question because if you Pin too little, there really isnâ€™t a reason to follow you, while if you Pin too much, you just get annoying.So is there a magical number of times to Pin a day to help you get more Pinterest followers?That was the question I explored recently analyzing 10 different studiesÂ to find a recommended minimum, maximum, and a solid starting point for how often to Pin.Hereâ€™s what that research uncovered:Pinterest is a high volume sharing communityâ€”so error on the side of more engagement than less.With her more than 1.6 million followers on Pinterest, Kim Vij knows a thing or two about building an audience. She says:Itâ€™s probably the quickest ways to lose followers if all you do is pin tons of pins at the same time and focus most on you and your most recent post.Mitt Ray agrees with Kim, saying:Donâ€™t share everything at once: Instead of clouding your followersâ€™ feeds with your pins all at once, time your pins to go out at regular intervals.So, whatâ€™s the best approach?Hereâ€™s an example of what your daily Pin schedule could look like to help you visualize your work:By this point, youâ€™re pretty much a follower-generating machine. You know how to:Now go build an audience thatâ€™ll help you grow your blog.Â Youâ€™ve got this!Click To Tweet
Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?
