column12: Fortunately, weâ€™re here to help you figure out which tools are most essential for the majority of content marketers and bloggers.Before we go any further, we need to clarify a few things.This post is not:This post is:The majority (but not all) of these tools are options we use ourselves here at CoSchedule. By the time youâ€™re done reading, youâ€™ll have everything you need to fill your content marketing toolkit.Use this table of contents to navigate:Ready to take a deeper dive? Letâ€™s do this.Youâ€™ve probably heard the quote, â€œFailure to plan is planning to fail.â€Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Itâ€™s a borderline cliche, but itâ€™s also completely accurate.Knowing what youâ€™re going to do in advance is important. Proper planning up front will help guide your efforts throughout your entire workflow, and can make or break your contentâ€™s chances for success.To get yourself organized (and to stay that way), itâ€™s helpful to have some productivity tools on hand.Recommended Reading:Getting organized as a content marketer or blogger doesnâ€™t have to break the bank. Here are some essentials for your toolbox.Thereâ€™s no easier way to manage a meeting and event calendar with a team than using Google Calendar. Itâ€™s free and ensures everyone has visibility to when people will be unavailable and when meetings are scheduled.Itâ€™s free and it works well. It also eliminates team members from saying they didnâ€™t get the memo on when a meeting is happening.Schedule your meetings, conference calls, client appointments, or anything else thatâ€™s helpful for your team to know about (or just for yourself to remember). Plus,Â you can connect CoSchedule to your Google CalendarÂ (although your calendar content will be read-only).If you havenâ€™t triedÂ Evernote, itâ€™s time to change that. Evernote is an extremely powerful note-taking and task management app. It also syncs across desktop and mobile devices, so you can access your notes and documents no matter where you are.The free plan offers a useful amount of features, but premium plans are reasonably priced and worth considering for greater functionality and flexibility.Evernote offers a secure means of storing and sharing notes and allows you to work on documents with your team.Evernote has an enormous number of applications that are useful for marketers and bloggers.Â Hereâ€™s just a handful of ideas on how to use Evernote with your content:Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Recommended Reading:Â How To Use Evernote For Blogging To Boost Your EfficiencyConsistently generating awesome content marketing ideas is one of the biggest challenges we all face as content marketers.Itâ€™s a good thing there are a lot of useful tools and hacks out there that youÂ can leverage to come up with more quality ideas faster than youÂ can rather than just relying on sheer imagination and mental power alone.Here are some of our favorite tools and techniques:FeedlyÂ is a news and blog aggregator that pulls in feeds from selected sources into one place. Think of it as a successor to the sorely missed Google Reader.Not only is it a good idea to keep tabs on the latest news and trends in your industry or niche, but it can also be a good way to stoke your own creativity. When you know what topics are trending and what other forms of content are being created, it will help you identify what you can do better, or what unique perspective you can add on to your own blog.Twitterâ€™s direct applications for content marketing are pretty obvious.Â What might be less obviousÂ is how to use Twitter to monitor trends andÂ come up with hotÂ content marketing ideas.Twitter isÂ essential for sharing content, interacting with influencers, and following your interests. That much you probably know. However, there are a few ways to use Twitter as a tool for generating content marketing ideas that you might have overlooked.The best ways to use Twitter for content ideation is to:Recommended Reading:Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Want to find the top-performing content on a keyword or topic? Then you want to use BuzzSumo.Itâ€™s extremely effective at surfacing the best content on a given topic or keyword quickly. Once you know what youâ€™re up against, you can strategize ways to make your content better from what already exists on the Web.Youâ€™ll seeÂ what other content is already out there on a topic or keywordÂ toÂ help spark your imagination.Ever wish you could just pop a few words into a form and get a weekâ€™s worth of content ideas in an instant? If so, then HubSpotâ€™s Blog Topic GeneratorÂ is exactly what youâ€™re looking for.Itâ€™s a quick and easy means of kickstarting your creative process, even if you donâ€™t end up using the exact ideas or headlines it suggests.The uses for this tool go beyond just generating ideas for blog posts.Try expanding out from using the topic generator to get more than just new blog title ideas. Why not try it to include downloadable guides, landing pages, slide decks, or other types of content?Itâ€™s better to think of the suggestions it provides as a starting point for brainstorming rather than something that will produce the final concepts youâ€™ll build content around.Keyword research is difficult to do well. However, it remains a vitally important piece of any content strategy.After all, if content marketing is all about serving users the information they need when theyâ€™re looking for it, then it helps to know which terms and topics are being searched (and making sure you have content to address those areas).Itâ€™s hard work, but using these tools can help.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Free and easy to use, Googleâ€™s Keyword PlannerÂ belongs in every content marketerâ€™s toolset.Back in the day (re: 2013), Googleâ€™s keyword research tool used to show exact keyword search volumes for specific terms.Â Now, it shows the number of timesÂ a keyword generates a paid ad in the SERPs (search engine result pages). While thatâ€™s great if youâ€™re into paid ads, thisÂ has led to some criticism around its usefulness if youâ€™re targeting organic search (as opposed to bidding on pay-per-click ads).The two main uses for this tool are to generate lists of potential keywords, and estimate how many people are searching for specific keywords.

KeywordiniÂ is a free tool offered by the SEO software service provider SERPs.com.It offers another data point for your keyword research. The results it provides also appear to be slightly different than what youâ€™ll find in Googleâ€™s Keyword Planner or Mozâ€™s Keyword Difficulty Tool.This one is simple:Â Type in a keyword or topic and itâ€™ll spit out a ton of related keywords, along with their estimated search volumes. Itâ€™s like having the ability to find related keywords and search volumes from Googleâ€™s keyword planner in one screen rather than two.While Googleâ€™s Keyword Planner gives you an idea of how competitive keywords are, the Moz Keyword Difficulty ToolÂ (included in Mozâ€™s premium software service suite, which weâ€™ll talk about in more detail later on), can give you a bit better of an idea on exactly how hard itâ€™ll be to rank for a given keyword.Itâ€™s one thing to target keywords with high search volume. Itâ€™s something else entirely to actually succeed in that goal.Â Sometimes, targeting keywords with less volume and less competition can be better than going after the most popular search terms.Once youâ€™ve got a list of keywords generated from other tools (like the Keyword Planner, Keywordini, Keyword.io, Ubersuggest, or any other tool you prefer), use Mozâ€™s Keyword Difficulty ToolÂ to determine your odds of ranking for those keywords. The higher the difficulty percentage, the more work youâ€™ll have to do to rank.Hereâ€™s a step-by-step guide to help you use the tool to choose your keywords:For more information on how to leverage this tool, check out Mozâ€™s detailed Keyword Difficulty Tool help guide.Before the Internet, great writers relied on nothing but sheer grit and determination to improve their writing. They also walked 15 miles uphill both ways in blizzard conditions to the nearest library to find reference material.Those were dark times (the depths of which have been only slightly exaggerated).Fortunately for you, there are now tons of tools available to help you improve your writing. Here is a handful of essentials:TheÂ free headline analyzerÂ has proven popular. Not only are we grateful that so many people find it helpful, but we use it ourselves every time we write headlines for a blog post.Your headline is what will get the attention of yourÂ potential readers. The headline analyzer gives you an idea just how strong your headlines really are, removing any editorial guesswork.The best way to use the headline analyzer is to write tons of headlines in succession and compare your scores and grades.Being able to hand your copy over to Ernest Hemingway would be nice for feedback. Since thatâ€™s impossible, using the Hemingway appÂ is the next best thing.Hemingway can help you test the readability of your content, ensuring your message doesnâ€™t get lost in overly complex or poorly structured language.Once youâ€™ve downloaded the app, just copy and paste your text into the window. Youâ€™ll get an instant critique of your work. There isnâ€™t much more to it than that. Easy peasy!Plagiarism sucks. CopyscapeÂ makes sure your text doesnâ€™t already exist word-for-word elsewhere on the Web.Â You donâ€™t want people thinking this about youÂ if they find out you plagiarized them:Plus, you could get in a lot of trouble. So stay away from plagiarism with Copyscape. Grammarly also has an option to check for plagiarism.You donâ€™t want to create the appearance that you stole someone elseâ€™s work (even if the inverse is actually true). Also, duplicate content is a major issue for SEO, since it makes it more difficult for search engines to know which page including that content to serve in search results.Depending on what kind of blog or business you run, dedicated landing pages can be an excellent way to target keywords or create attractive destination pages for social media, email, and PPC campaigns.LeadPagesÂ is a simple software tool you can use to build lead-generation landing pages without knowing any code. InstapageÂ is another landing page company that offers a free version.One of the main reasons to use LeadPages is that the results it produces are impressive, especially considering its ease of use. If youâ€™re looking for a way to build a landing page with a contact form in order to build your email list, then look no further.If you have a piece of content like a downloadable white paper or ebook, building a landing page with gated access (where users exchange their email address for your content) is a great way to build your email list and promote your content at the same time.Want to know how to do this exactly? Check out LeadPagesâ€™ own email list building video course:Having strong visual content is non-optional if you want to create strong blog posts.However, not all of us are designers by trade. Nor does every content marketer or blogger have the privilege of working with someone who does possess a proficient design skillset. Fortunately, there are plenty of tools that can help fill this gap (many of which weâ€™ve covered on the CoSchedule blog in the past, and for good reason).You canâ€™t talk about Web-based design tools without talking about CanvaÂ (which is probably why weâ€™ve been talking about them a lot). Itâ€™s simple, easy to use, and gets the job done with minimal fuss.The biggest reason to use Canva is that you need a variety of graphic styles to fit all kinds of different content formats (social media, email headers, website headers, and much more), but you donâ€™t have the time to design original graphics with pro tools like Photoshop yourself.Hereâ€™s an example of something you could make with Canva relatively quickly (note this is just a default template):Whether youâ€™re creating images for a blog post, social media post, presentation, website banner, or even print collateral, it offers a flexible platform with an impressive level of customization for a template-based tool.Recommended Reading:While you can create infographics with Canva too, Infogr.amÂ is another option to consider if youâ€™re looking for something that builds infographics specifically.People love infographics. They provide an easily digestible way to visualize data, and Infogr.am makes them easy to create. Alternatively, you might also want to try PiktochartÂ out, too.If you need to build an infographic for a blog post fast, this is your go-to tool. Itâ€™s also helpful for potentially getting some extra views on your infographic, since what you create is searchable in Infogr.amâ€™s index:While Photoshop remains the reigning king of industry-standard graphic manipulation tools, itâ€™s worth giving a shout out to GIMPÂ here, too. If youâ€™re unfamiliar, GIMP (which stands for GNU Image Manipulation Program) is a free and open-source alternative to Photoshop that works in much the same way as Adobeâ€™s staple imaging software.The clearest reason to use GIMP over Photoshop is that itâ€™s free. Itâ€™s often said to be a little less intuitive than Photoshop, and professional designers used to working with an Adobe software may find it limiting in some ways, or just difficult to relearn. However, for the budget-conscious (and we know a good portion of our readers are working on limited budgets), GIMP is impressively full-featured and packs enough power for the majority of folks out there to accomplish what they need.Youâ€™ll need to develop some actual design chops to use GIMP well, but if you canâ€™t afford Photoshop, it will be a godsend. If you need help getting started, try reading these official GIMP tutorials.Recommended Reading:Search engine optimization isnâ€™t easy, and itâ€™s even tougher to do it without the right resources.SEO BookÂ makes a variety of tools available for free. Hereâ€™s a quick look at what they offer (members only tools are available by signing up for free):The biggest appeal here is cost. While the tools provided arenâ€™t as fully featured as premium alternatives, they also wonâ€™t cost you anything. Plus, theyâ€™re enough to get a surprising amount of work done.One of the most useful tools SEO Book offers is their Rank Checker. Itâ€™s a free FireFox extension that allows you to check your search rankings on a given keyword. Check out this video to see how it works:This tool does have some limitations. You have to put in keywords one at a time, and itâ€™s only available for FireFox. Plus, its results can be misleading (since the tool counts local search listings the same as normal search results, it might say you rank 13th, even though you rank 10th).If you canâ€™t afford Moz, Raven Tools, or something similar for keyword rank tracking, itâ€™s the next best thing.Widely considered the industry-standard when it comes to WordPress plugins for SEO, YoastÂ is a must-have for any blog.Simply put, itâ€™s probably the single most essential SEO plugin that every WordPress blog needs.At its most basic level, Yoast is useful for custom editing your blog post title tags and meta descriptions.Itâ€™s also handy for quickly analyzing your on-page optimization efforts and showing where you can improve your post for SEO. If youâ€™re ready to get more technical, it can also be used to implement XML sitemaps, edit your robots.txt file, create breadcrumb navigation trails, and more (if none of this makes sense, Yoast provides a good overview of the featuresÂ on their website).MozÂ is a premium all-in-one SEO and content marketing software platform. In addition to checking keyword ranking difficulty (like we mentioned earlier in this post), it lets you track keyword rankings, analyze backlinks, diagnose technical issues, check important on-page factors for SEO, and much more. If you can afford it, itâ€™s well worth the asking price.If SEO is critical for your business, then having a dedicated platform can quickly pay for itself. While there is a lot of competition in this space, Moz is perhaps one of the most widely recognized options availableÂ and is easy enough to use for any content marketer to figure out without sacrificing power or capability.Having a full SEO platform (whether you use Moz or a similar competitor like Raven Tools) at your disposal puts an incredible amount of power at your fingertips.There are many different things that Moz lets you track. We arenâ€™t going to get into how to use each and every one of these aspects of Moz, because you can find out more on how to use Moz from them.The biggest reason to invest in something like Moz is that in most cases, itâ€™s more cost effective than trying to perform these tasks manually, or trying to cobble together a useful toolset solely from standalone tools that just perform one or a few of these tasks (although those types of tools have a place, too).Keep in mind that Moz is a complex tool that offers an incredible amount of power. While we donâ€™t have room to walk through all of its capabilities, Mozâ€™sÂ Help Hub and Q&A Forum are both great resources to find assistance.Backlinks from other websites remain crucial for strong SEO in 2016.AhrefsÂ (as well as competitor Majestic, which can be equally recommended) allows you to go in-depth with analyzing links that point back to your blog or website, as well as helping you identify opportunities to earn fresh links.While Moz, Raven Tools, and other comprehensive SEO suites offer similar functionality (in fact, Moz and many others integrate with Majestic for backlink data), Ahrefs offers more dedicated power to link-related tasks. Plus, the cost isnâ€™t too exorbitant to justify investing in another tool in addition to other SEO tools you may be using.The main use case for something like Ahrefs is to take a deep dive into your backlink profile, as well as to do competitive research whoâ€™s linking to your competition. Itâ€™s also useful for finding top-performing content on a given topic (similar to BuzzSumo), detecting crawl errors, and uncovering which keywords your competitors are ranking for. Itâ€™s all good stuff to keep tabs on.Doing social media marketing well has never been more challenging or more important. However, marketers and bloggers have never had more tools at their disposal to give themselves a competitive edge, either.We have an obvious bias here because we built CoSchedule to make managing and scheduling social media promotion for your blog posts easy.Youâ€™ll be able to easily schedule social media posts and to promote your blog posts all in one dashboard. Thatâ€™s a big time saver.Our tool is built to have a multitude of uses throughout your content marketing workflow. However, when it comes to social media marketing, one application for CoSchedule you may not have considered is scheduling standalone social mediaÂ content that isnâ€™t connected to a blog post.You might just want to schedule social media posts on their own, or even drop curated content into your content calendar to publish in the future.WP Open GraphÂ is a WordPress plugin that lets you add Open Graph metaÂ data to your blog posts so you can better control how theyâ€™ll appear when you share posts on that platform.Ever tried sharing a blog post on Facebook, LinkedIn, or Google+ and got frustrated when you couldnâ€™t quite control their appearance without a hassle?Â Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s worth considering using this plugin.Youâ€™ll be able to control the appearance of your blog posts on Facebook.However, it can also be used on static pages on your WordPress website as well. Simply find the plugin hereÂ and install it on your WordPress blog. From there, WP Open Graph works in the background with minimal work, automatically pulling your Featured Image in to ensure your blog posts look great on social media.If you arenâ€™t currently doing any email marketing, now is the time to get started. Email delivers unbeatable ROI, and with the right tools, it doesnâ€™t have to be too difficult or time consuming.MailChimp makes it easy to build visually appealing e-newsletters. The free version offers an impressive amount of power, while premium plans allow you to add features and send an unlimited number of emails.If youâ€™re sending straight-forward text email newsletters without any visual styling (which may work for you), then youâ€™re missing an opportunity to make your emails more eye-catching.One creative way to use MailChimp is toÂ integrate it with your LeadPages landing page, feeding your email leads straight into your mailing list in MailChimp. Be sure to read MailChimpâ€™s help and getting started docs.Recommended Reading:Â 21+ Easy Ways To Build An Email List That Will Skyrocket By 552% In 1 YearWhile there are a lot of advanced email marketing platforms out there, Campaign Monitor is the one we use at CoSchedule. We like the simplicity of its editing tools and ease of use when it comes to managing our email list.Campaign Monitor makes managing monstrous email lists easier.The use cases for Campaign Monitor are essentially the same as MailChimp, but for when you need something more powerful that allows you to manage a larger subscriber list. They have a ton of helpful resources to get you going.Think your ears are burning? Know who is talking about your blog or brand on the Web with a couple simple tools.Google Alerts is free to set up and will send you email notifications when certain keywords appear in news articles or blog posts. It sometimes misses things, but works well for the most part.Itâ€™s important to keep tabs on who is paying attention to your content and your brand. It can help you identify potential brands to partner with, keep you notified of potential linking opportunities (say, if someone mentions your name but doesnâ€™t link back to your blog, you can always reach out to request a link).Create a short list of names people might use to refer to your brand or blog, put them into your Google Alerts account, and let the mentions roll into your email. For more on how to use it, Google has a help doc on that here.You can also use Google Alerts to get ideas for content curation. We covered a few other tools that will help with content curation in a post on social media best practices.If you need something more robust than Google Alerts, MentionÂ should fit the bill. It goes beyond simple Web monitoring and adds social media monitoring for Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, YouTube, and more.Not only is it important to see what people are saying about your blog or brand, but itâ€™s also important to respond to those folks (when and where appropriate). Thatâ€™s a lot easier to do expediently when you have one place to log into.When you want to go beyond what Google Alerts can offer, and want to pull in brand mentions from across the Web and your social channels all in one place, Mention is your go-to tool. Mention has a bunch of great tutorial videos you should check out on YouTube.Modern marketing is all about data. While big data platforms can be expensive and far out of reach for many solo bloggers and in-house marketing teams in small business settings (which is the majority of our readers), you still have options for gathering data to help drive better business decisions.Google AnalyticsÂ is the one data platform that every blogger and content marketer needs to be paying attention to, with 75% of our 2016 Better Marketing Survey takers saying they use it to monitor their performance.If youâ€™ve neglected setting up Google Analytics (itâ€™s not too difficult to get up and running, but configuring and customizing it properly admittedly can get tricky), it provides an incredible wealth of data about your blog and/or website.One way to get the most from Google Analytics is to use custom dashboards that will help present specific data you need for certain purposes. For example, if you wanted a way to just analyze referral traffic from social media, you could set up a custom dashboard with relevant social media data.If you need help, Google provides plenty of user-created custom dashboards and templates that you can download and use without having to configure them yourself. Take a look around their Analytics Solutions Gallery to find what you need.When sorting through our 2016 Better Marketer Survey data, we expected a lot of readers would report using Google Analytics. However, we were surprised to see just 16% of respondents use Google Search Console. That could be partially due to confusion because Search Console used to be called Google Webmaster Tools (a title some people still use to refer to it conversationally).Itâ€™s invaluable for helping to diagnose technical issues on your blog or website.Here are just a handful of applications inside Google Search Console:If you need help getting started, Moz has created an excellent Google Search Console guideÂ that you may find useful.Want to pull all your social media stats into one dashboard for free? SumAllÂ is what you need.Itâ€™s a convenient no-cost tool that helps you measure your social media performance. Itâ€™s an automatic report generation that is particularly useful and efficient.Just sign up, connect your social media accounts, and wait for all that sweet data to roll in. Itâ€™s a fairly simple tool that can help save time by letting you see everything in one place. While SumAll used to offer a free plan, it now requires a paid subscription.By now, you should have a solid grasp on the essential tools that every blogger and marketer needs. Hopefully, youâ€™ve gained a better understanding of how to use them as well.Click To Tweet

column12: To answer your question of how often to blog,Â itâ€™d be all too easy for me to just say, â€œHey there, just do a blog schedule of one post per week,â€ and call this post complete.But. Iâ€™m a nerd. And I donâ€™t believe that every blog is created equal, nor does it have the same audience. So there is no one clear way to answer that question other than to use your own data to help you find the perfect frequency and consistencyÂ that will help you grow.And to do that, weâ€™re going to use maths. Yes. Maths. Now, I know youâ€™re a creative person and if youâ€™re anything like me, you probably loathed any class that had anything to do with numbers when you were back in school.So Iâ€™m going to walk you through how often to blog by helping you fill out your content calendar template that will translate your raw data into some super cool insights. When youâ€™re done reading this post, youâ€™ll know:This is the exact process weâ€™ve used at CoSchedule to grow traffic to new blog posts by 299%. The idea is simple: Replicate the success from yourÂ best-performing content to improve every new post youÂ publish. And you can do it, too.Get out your calculators because itâ€™s about to rain numbers up in here. (See, I canâ€™t even make a good math joke.)Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Youâ€™re about to go through aÂ few steps with your data. To keep you from becoming overwhelmed, just know that the final outcome of this process will be the exact number of blog posts you need to publish to reach your goals.When you follow these steps, youâ€™llÂ solve the frequency problem which leads directly into solving the consistency problem.Brainstorm the reasons why youâ€™re blogging.Â It sounds silly because it might feelÂ obvious, but the practice will helpÂ you hone in on the right ways to measure your success.For example, letâ€™s say you use inbound marketing through your blogÂ to sell a product. Thatâ€™s terrific! While thatâ€™s your big picture goal,Â think about how your blog can actually contribute to that goal through traffic, email subscribers, and trial conversions.For the sake of this postâ€”and to give you an example to follow through this processâ€”letâ€™s say you choose to measure your success through increasing traffic. Judging fromÂ the data you gave us in the Better Marketer Survey, thatâ€™sÂ why you blogâ€”to introduce your business to lots of people online.So: I am blogging to increase traffic.Now itâ€™s time to understand the exact metric youâ€™ll measure and find the tool that will give you that data.AÂ robust and free tool to start with is Google Analytics.Â The tool will help you trackÂ general traffic metrics and also helps you track your conversion steps for goals like email subscriptions and trial signups.In the case for the example youâ€™re following, you can use Google Analytics to measure increasing traffic with the metric of page views.So:Â For my broad goal to increase traffic, Iâ€™m going to measure success with this specific metric: page views.Look at the past several months to find the average amount you receive for that metric. Youâ€™ll use this data to help you understand howÂ the changes youâ€™ll make in frequency and consistency are helping you reach your goal.For example, if youâ€™re measuring page views, take a look atÂ your past three monthâ€™s individual contribution to that metric. Then average the three numbers to gauge an average monthâ€™s performance over the past quarter.So: Iâ€™m going to look at how many average page views I got per month over the last three months.Now all you have to do is gather the data for your metric and find the average. Use this equation to get started:Â __________ {sum of all metricÂ in the sample} / __________ {# of monthsÂ in the sample} =Â __________ {average monthÂ contribution}.You just did some math. Very nice.You need a baselineÂ number from an average blog post. That means that youâ€™ll need to review the same metric from several blog posts, giving them all the same opportunity to be successful.In other words, you need to find outÂ the amount each post in a sample contributed to yourÂ metric within a certain period of time.Back to the example youâ€™re followingâ€”you need to look at a nice sample size of blog posts (10 at least), and reviewÂ how many page views each post delivered in the first 30 days after being published. The 30-day period means each post got an equal opportunity (more or less) to contribute to the metric.So: Iâ€™m going to look at how many page views 10 blog posts received in the first 30 days after they were published.Now itâ€™s time to gather the data. Grab your content calendar template and enter in all of the URLs of the blog posts youâ€™ll include in your sample, then grab the data for yourÂ baseline time period for each of those URLs.Find the average metric number forÂ all of the blog posts in the sample by using this equation: __________ {sum of metric from all posts in the sample} / __________ {# of posts in the sample} =Â __________ {average post contribution}.This is where it gets really fun. :)Now you can actually setÂ real goals based on data so you know they will be realistically achievable while also helping you shoot for growth.If you set goals before this point, you have no data-driven way to understand how each post you publish will contribute to your larger picture. It would be a guessâ€”which will make your content calendar feel a whole lot more stressful.Anyway, SMART goals, as it were, stands for:Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?The good news is that youâ€™ve done nearly all of thisÂ already byÂ walking through this process right now. Itâ€™s the aspirational side of things that makes a great goal andÂ pushes you into continued growth.A good goal is at least 10x growth month over month to keep you focused on projects that will help you truly grow. That means, youâ€™ll want at least a 10% month-over-month increase withÂ your metric.Back to your example: Letâ€™s sayÂ you get 10,000 page views a month. 10% more than that is 11,000, so thatâ€™s your aspirational goal for next month.Do this: __________ {average month contribution} Ã—Â 1.__________ {% aspirational growth} = __________ {new month contribution goal}.By this point, you know your aspirational goal for your content calendar for next month. Luckily for you, you also know how much each blog post contributes to that metric.So now you can simply add up how many blog posts you need to publish next month to reach your goal.Following your example, letâ€™s say an average blog post of yours gets 2,500 page views. To exceedÂ your monthly aspirational goal of 11,000 page views, youâ€™d need to publish fiveÂ blog posts next month (and you can realistically predict youâ€™ll get 12,500 page views).Just follow this equation: __________ {new month contribution goal} /Â __________ {average post contribution} =Â __________ {# of posts needed to reach your goal}.Note: This formula completely leaves out long-tail metrics from blog posts youâ€™ve published in the past. It is, however, a usefulÂ guideÂ to help you understand how much more frequently you could blog to reach your goals.Use your best judgment to understand how much more youâ€™ll need to publish and remember: SMART goals have to be realistically achievable.Youâ€™ll learn how to plan your calendar for long-term growth in a second, I promise.Now, this process will always suggest that you need to publish more contentâ€”increase your publishing frequencyâ€”to reach your aspirational goal.Like doing anything new, there is a learning curve thatÂ suggests adding more new things to your plate takes a bit longer initially than after you master the craft.You know those marathon runners? They donâ€™t start out by running 26.2 miles on their first day. They train themselves by runningÂ shorter distances to build up the tolerance to make it all the way through the marathon. Theyâ€™re strict on their running schedules and commit to success.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?You need to have a similar commitmentÂ with your content calendar if youâ€™re going to experience 299% more success than you are today. And that also means you need to schedule time for yourself to build up your publishing endurance.Back to that example: Letâ€™s say you normally publish four new blog posts that each earn 2,500 page views a monthâ€”one every week that bring in a monthly total of 10,000 page views. To reach your aspirational goal of 11,000 page views, youâ€™d like to publish fiveÂ posts next month.Â That means youâ€™ll publish one extra post nextÂ monthÂ to exceed your aspirational goal of 11,000 monthly page views by actually hitting 12,500.See how that works?PlanÂ content in your calendar so that you can build up the tolerance to publish much more content:After youÂ successfully publish your extra content, reflect on the process by asking yourself three simple questions:Constant iteration and improvement will help you build up your publishing endurance to help you increase your blogging frequency while also sharing content regularly and consistently.But what if you donâ€™t want to publish more content, but rather, get more results from every blog post you plan to publish? Itâ€™s totally possible.Youâ€™ve probably had a post or two hit it out of the park. So wouldnâ€™t it be great if every post you wrote from this point forward had the same success?Itâ€™s a question we asked ourselves at CoSchedule and figured out the process to help us strategically choose content to create that we know youâ€™ll dig to help us reach our goals faster and make the effort of writing a blog post pay off that much more.And, itâ€™s a process you can do with your content, too. How? You ask. Well,Â allow me to show you step by step.Whip out your content calendar template and create a list ofÂ every one of your blog postsâ€™ URLs fromÂ at least the past nine months. You can go longer if you wantâ€”the point is to get a largeÂ sample.Critically think about what makes a successful blog post on your site.For this exercise, I scrutinized CoSchedule content and came up with four categories I felt made our content successful.Â You can start with these questions for your blog, too; or if you feel there is something else unique about your blog that makes your content successful in a different way, swapÂ out a question.Keyword: Successful posts target a keyword and are optimized to rank well for that keyword to continue bringing in long-term traffic from an audience who oftenÂ doesnâ€™t already know you. By optimizing your content from the get-go, you continue getting traffic and building your audience well into the future without additional promotion.Question to ask yourself: Was the keyword well-chosen (for search volume and difficulty) and optimized throughout the post to help me get long-term traffic?Topic:Â Next, successful blog posts connect the keyword people use to find your content into the angle or unique value proposition for a problem theyâ€™d like to resolve. This shows your audienceâ€”even newcomersâ€”that youâ€™re deeply in tune with their challenges and youâ€™re dedicated to helping themÂ overcome their hurdles.Question to ask yourself: Was this a topic my readers would be deeply interested in learning more about?Research: Successful content backs up its claims with thorough research that proves why your advice is credible and worth following. Your credibility willÂ build a following of readers who keep coming back.Question to ask yourself: Was this post deeply researched to share unique and better information than any other source on the Internet?Comprehensiveness: Call it complete, in-depth, or actionable.Â Comprehensiveness has nothing to do with word count, but rather, when you decide to tackle a topic that you give it everything youâ€™ve got to go deep into the detail instead of just publishing catchy blog titles with content that barely scratches the surface of the promise you make in your value proposition.Question to ask yourself: Did the post turn the research into actionable, exhaustive how-to adviceÂ andÂ end onlyÂ when the entire story was complete?Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?At this point, youâ€™re basing all of your thoughts on gut instinct: Was this postÂ successful or not? Thereâ€™s no data involved whatsoever yet. Youâ€™re just aiming to translate your gut into a grade. Kinda like a teacher grading your homework.For each of the questions, rank every post in your list onÂ a 1 to 3 scale for each of the four categoriesÂ of successful content: keyword, topic, research, comprehensiveness. 1 means the post isÂ a stinker in that category whereas a 3 means itâ€™s totally awesome.Go ahead and use your content calendar template to grade your content in each of the four categories you feel make your content successful. When youâ€™re done, add up each blog postâ€™sÂ grade with the highest score a single post can receive being a 12 and the lowest possible being a 4.Now itâ€™s time to find the contributionÂ each blog post delivers to your aspirational goal. In your content calendar template, track the metric for the first 30 days after a blog post publishes.Additionally,Â grab the data from the following two months to give you a complete quarterâ€™s worth of data.From here,Â you can measure the return on investment for every blog postÂ after its first monthâ€™s worth of performance to help you predict how your blog posts will contribute to your goals a full two months after they publish. This is where youâ€™ll learn more about that part I noted for residual long-term metrics and can add it into play as you improve your content calendar.Go into your content calendar template and sortÂ your blog posts according to the grades you ranked them (12 being the highest and should be at the top of your sortedÂ list).Go ahead and highlight your top five blog posts with redÂ (#1), orangeÂ (#2), yellowÂ (#3), greenÂ (#4), and blueÂ (#5).Now sortÂ all of your posts again according to the first 30 days they contribute to your metrics with the highest contributing post at the top of your list.You can see from your color coding how your gut actually translates into your most successful content. If your gut translated correctly, your topÂ five posts should still beÂ red, orange, yellow, green, and blue.Soâ€¦ Were you right? Were you wrong? Either way, there are lots of lessons you can learn from this process with the two biggest ones being:Do you see where youâ€™re going with this?No more guessing. No more getting close but not quite right.Dissect the top five posts according to their contribution to yourÂ aspirational goal and replicate the success from your top-performing content.Here are a few questions you can ask yourself as you review that content:You get the picture. Figure out all theÂ reasons why your audience loved those posts and repeat those elementsÂ in the new posts you plan on your content calendar.This process will help you get more out of every blog post you publish so you donâ€™t have to publish more content, but rather, improve the quality of the content you publish.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Well, youâ€™ve just gone through a lot. You know:But hereâ€™s the thing: You just foundÂ your best-performing blog postsÂ that you can optimize even further and republish to get even more out of them.This simple republishing process will help you:Yeah, sold you, right? Finally: Something easy to fill up your content calendar. :)Lucky you! You already found your top-performing blog posts according to your aspirational goal. The only other qualifier for republishingÂ is to make sureÂ that the post you choose is at least six month old.The older, the better, since you donâ€™t want to accidentally share something thatâ€™s somewhat new with your audience who may have already seen it.AddingÂ more relevant content into your older blog post adds tons of value for your readersâ€”even if they saw the original piece in the past. And according to Brian Deanâ€™s research on the top 200 ranking factors Google uses in its search algorithm,Â Google also likes to seeÂ you refreshing your content.To top it off, whenÂ you add more actionable advice to your contentÂ andÂ increaseÂ the length of your blog post, you have a higher likelihood of ranking well in search engines.Add new data: There came a point when you had to publish the post originally. There were probably other sources of data that you didnâ€™t include in your initial content because you didnâ€™t find themÂ at the time or they didnâ€™t even exist because theyâ€™re so new.That type of research can help keep your advice relevantâ€”or could even help you make a couple new points that you didnâ€™t think about before.Replace outdated information: When you continue researching your blog post, you might find new information that disputes your original suggestions.For example, in a post we republished called â€œ25 Growth Hacks That Will Amplify Your Content Marketingâ€œ, I found out that one of the growth hacks from the original postÂ wasnâ€™t valid anymore because the website we referenced went out of business. I replaced that outdated information with a new growth hack that was similarÂ but much more timely than the original idea.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Add more awesome advice: With time comes more experience. Think about how authors re-release their books several years after their original version with new edits and insights theyâ€™ve learned after getting published. Use the same process to add additional advice that builds on your original thought process to add more value.A way we do this at CoSchedule is by analyzing all of the how-to information in an older blog post before we republish.If we give advice on, say, â€œmake an infographic to get more social sharesâ€, weâ€™llÂ back up the claim with new data that proves infographics still get more social shares than any other type of visual content. Then weâ€™ll also give the step-by-step guidance on how to create that infographic (or link to a new blog post with lots more detail).See what I did there?You can apply the same process to your blog post before you republish it by analyzing areas you can flesh out with further step-by-step, actionable guidance.Optimize the post for keywords: Yeah, you probably targeted a keyword in your blog post originally. But the keyword game is changing a little bit, and it turns out you can target multiple related keywords in one blog post to get traffic from several different search terms.While Iâ€™ve taken a stab at keyword optimization, Iâ€™ll let Rand from Moz teach you how to do this because heâ€™s wicked smart:Essentially, based on your original keyword, find synonyms or related keywords that will help you rank for a category-type of search.Optimize for email subscriber conversions: A lot of you areÂ building your email list to keep your readers coming back for more of your awesome content. Thatâ€™s a terrific idea, so youâ€™ll love hearing that adding content upgrades into your blog posts can help you increase the number of email subscribers you receive from any blog postâ€”including the ones youâ€™re optimizing and republishing.Let me explain a bit about content upgrades: Since we started including bonus content like infographics, templates, worksheets, guides, and checklists in every blog post we publish here at CoSchedule, weâ€™ve been able to increase our email subscribers by 552% in one year. Seriously.And you can experience similarÂ success:Hereâ€™sÂ how Neil Patel does this exact content upgrade process using LeadPagesâ€™ LeadBoxes:Neil Patel uses LeadBoxes from LeadPages to add content upgrades into his content to turn traffic into email subscribers.You can do it, too. And itâ€™s especially handy for turning your high-trafficked posts into subscriber-generating machines.You can keep the republishing process simple to work through these projects faster than you would when youâ€™d write a brand new post.Â This is how to republish a blog post in WordPress:Now, if youâ€™d like to get a little picky about your blog and have that republishedÂ post show up on your home page, you could always go into the original post and change itÂ to a time in the recent past (like say 30 minutes ago).Just be weary about accidentallyÂ changing the date on your already-published post to republish in the futureâ€”itâ€™s no good unless youâ€™re Michael J. Fox. :)Listen, I know this sounds like a lot, so hear me out:Why this process is worth every second you spend doing itÂ even though youâ€™re probablyÂ scared of what you read.Youâ€™re thinking right now:This guyâ€™s crazy. I donâ€™t have time for this!To which Iâ€™m thinking:How will you be able toÂ improve without knowingÂ how what youâ€™ve doneâ€”and what you plan to doâ€”has impacted your goal?And my bro Abraham Lincoln is backing me up:Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.If you really want to throw efficiency in the mix, consider this: Productivity is only as good as the content you produce and how itÂ reaches your goal. Using your time to create effective content is far better than being efficient with your time.Using your time to create effective content is far better than being efficient with your time.Click To TweetHeck, Todd Henry sums it up best in his book,Â The Accidental Creative: How To Be Brilliant At A Momentâ€™s Notice:We must learn to spend our time effectively rather than obsessing about efficiency.Do this, and I guarantee your content calendar will deliver the results youâ€™re looking for.#RantOverI wouldnâ€™t give you any advice I wouldnâ€™t follow myself.Â This process is exactly how we plan our content calendar at CoSchedule, and itâ€™sÂ helped us keep our content calendar on track and reach our aspirational goals to grow super fast.Good luck with your content calendar!Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?PSâ€”When youâ€™re ready to get out of your content calendar template and into a tool designed to help you plan your content more efficiently than ever, try CoSchedule. Itâ€™s your social media and editorial calendar.

column1: 2016-03-23,http://coschedule.com/blog/best-time-to-send-email/,Best Time to Send Email Backed By 10 Data-Driven Studies,"The free blog post headline analyzer will score your overall headline quality and rate its ability to result in social shares, increased traffic, and SEO value.You probablyÂ found this postÂ after looking through several others searching for a real answer to the question, â€œWhen is the best time to send email?â€I say it that way because lots of sources outÂ there provide the same answer: It depends. And that answer isnâ€™t especiallyÂ helpful.SoÂ read assured, youâ€™re going to find the information you need in this post. And youâ€™ll also get a lot more.You see, the reason why you want to know the best times to send emailâ€”or the best daysâ€”is that you ultimately want more opens and more clickthroughs to get more traffic to your blog. And you want all of that because your email list is your most loyal audience whoâ€™ll share your content once they read it, which creates the snowball effect of more traffic, more subscribers, and more customer conversions.Can you getÂ all of that byÂ sending your emails at the best time? Itâ€™s a good place to start, so read this post to learn:Letâ€™s commence with the learninâ€™.Click To Tweet

column12: Whatâ€™s super cool about this sample of articles is that the research varies from studying billions (yes, seriously) of emails to more than 20 million, from case studies toÂ roundups. The data is diverse, but there are dots to connect thatâ€™ll help you send emailsÂ on the best days and at the best times.Here are the studies:And hereâ€™s the analysis:According to these studies, prioritize your send days in this order:Iâ€™ll note: Some of the studies mentioned high opens and clickthrough rates on Saturdays and Sundays. Well, those are also the days when the fewest emails are sent. So while the open rates may be higher in general, the actual number of emails opened is way lower.Not every study had visual representations of the dataÂ in them, but youâ€™ll find it interesting to see the similarity among the graphs that were present. Itâ€™s noteworthyÂ that most activity happens during the middle of the week withÂ only minor outliers. Hereâ€™s that data:GetResponse foundÂ the peak inbox activity happens on Thursdays. The second highest peak was on Wednesdays.Data from GetResponse.MailChimp also found high open rates on Thursdays, with a second peak on Tuesdays.Data from MailChimp.Further data from MailChimp and Wordstream suggests thatÂ Thursday and Tuesday are the best days to send emails.Data from Wordstream and MailChimp.Tuesdays get the most emails opened compared to any other day of the week though Saturdays may also be a good day to send email for its high open rate, according to data from Experian and analyzed by Customer.io.Data from Experian and Customer.io.HubSpot found that Tuesday is the best day to send email, followed with a tie for Monday and Wednesday.Data from HubSpot.MailerMailer found TuesdaysÂ win for opens, with Wednesday coming in at a close second. For clicks, Sundays win, with Tuesday coming in second place. Note that since Sunday hasÂ lowerÂ opens, itâ€™s likely easier to get that high of a clickthrough rate.Data from MailerMailer.Data from Dan Zarella and provided through GetResponse suggests sending emails on Saturday and Sunday and that itâ€™s best for both clicks and opens.Data from GetResponse and Dan Zarella.While many of the studies found varying results, here is how you can prioritize your send times based on data:Take a look at the similarities in these graphs for a lot more detail on the analysis.Morning between 9â€“11 a.m. is definitely the best time to send email according to Campaign Monitorâ€™s research. It looks like there is a peak at 10 a.m. Campaign MonitorÂ sums it up by saying that 53% of emails are opened during the workday between 9 a.m.â€“5 p.m.Data from Campaign Monitor.MailChimp confirms with Campaign Monitor that sending emailsÂ later in the morning between 10 a.m.â€“noon will get you the most opens.Â It looks like the best time to send email is at 10 a.m.Data from MailChimp.Surprisingly, different research from MailChimp and analyzed by Wordstream suggests there may also be a peak for opens in the afternoon. Wordstream saysÂ 2 p.m. is also a peak time to send email.Data from Wordstream and MailChimp.Data from Experian and cited through Customer.io suggestsÂ a similar approach to Wordstreamâ€™s analysis to send emails later in the day. Customer.io found that email opens are highest from 8 p.m.â€“midnight, with a second peak between 4â€“8 p.m.Customer.io suggests that while itâ€™s a common practice to checkÂ email in the mornings, most people are just beginning their day and may likely avoid email marketing in favor of productivity.Data from Experian and Customer.io.HubSpot researched open times to find late morning tends to get the most opens. Send emails at 11 a.m. for the best results.Data from HubSpot.Data from MailerMailer also suggests that sending emails in the late morning during work hours gets the best percentage of opens. Send your emails at 10 a.m.Data from MailerMailer.Dan Zarellaâ€™s research, as analyzed by GetResponse, suggests 6 a.m. is a peak time to send emails, followed by late in the evening from 8 p.m.â€“midnight.Data from GetResponse and Dan Zarella.Every one of the studies this post analyzes mentioned in some way that the best timesÂ to send emails depends onÂ your own audience.Hereâ€™s a memorable quote from Megan at Wordstream:Thatâ€™s the advice. Now ignore it.If thatâ€™s true, then why do so many studies offer similarÂ information that suggestsÂ sending emails on Tuesdays at 10 a.m.Â will be the most successful?Still, it does make sense to use these days and times to start a test for your own audience. As John from MailChimp notes:But keep in mind, the primary driver of engagement for your list is you: your content, your industry, the list youâ€™ve uploaded.Both Megan and JohnÂ are right, though. And thatâ€™s why you can use your own data and Google Analytics to help you sendÂ email more effectively.Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?There are two phases to understand the best times to send email to your audience:Itâ€™s really simple if you plan your work, then work your plan.Follow this outline to testÂ your days and times to send email. Regardless of how many emails you send during a week, you can walk through this process from first email to last email over the time frame that works best for you.Itâ€™s like a checklist for the days and times youâ€™ll send your next 12 emails:That is now your plan for the next 12 emails youâ€™ll send to your subscribers. Keep in mind, research also shows thatÂ 23% of your subscribers will open emails within 60 minutesÂ after you send them. So Itâ€™s fine to schedule your emails to send 30 minutes prior to theÂ peak time.What youâ€™re really after is understanding how much traffic your emails areÂ contributing to your blog. After all, these are your most loyal readers whoÂ read, share, and bring additional traffic to your site.So while you could go into your email service providerâ€™s dashboard to look at your open and clickthrough rates, an easier way to gauge the performance of your test is by using Google Analytics and reviewing your referral traffic from email.When you first open this report, youâ€™ll simply set the start date and end date to the times when you ran the test. Then select Email.Choose the date range of your test, then select â€œEmailâ€ in the Google Analytics custom report.Once you click through to filter your data to show only referral traffic from email, youâ€™ll see the best days that are giving you the most traffic listed in order according to page views.Â From there, you can click through again to see the best times by hour when you receive that traffic.This view shows the days of the week when you get the most traffic from email. Click through to see the best times on these specific days.This is probably the best place to start with your research. Something that has stuck with me from this analysis was a commentÂ from Mark Brownlow all the way back from 2009:
Another trap is to think of â€œbest dayâ€ and â€œbest time of dayâ€ as two separate issues. The best time to send depends on the day you send it. And vice versa.

That seems like good advice.Just like the first report, enter in the date range when you did your email test, then filter to see only referral traffic from Email.Set your date range of your test, then filter to see email only in your Google Analytics custom report.From there, youâ€™llÂ see your best times to send email based on data from your own audience.Review the best time to send email by hour according to your own traffic data.Itâ€™s that easy to set up your email test.But youÂ want even more traffic than youâ€™re already gettingâ€¦ so a good next step would be to get more opens. And the bestÂ way to improve that is by writing even better email subject lines.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Itâ€™s no secret that one of the primary drivers of opens is your email subject line. Itâ€™s the part that usually stands out the most in your subscribersâ€™ inboxes right from the get-go, making your first impression for the content youâ€™re sending.So if opens lead to clickthroughs, and opens come from awesome email subject lines, letâ€™s explore a few data-driven ways to write those subject lines so they help you reach your goal to get more traffic.There is a lot of advice out thereÂ to help you write better subject lines. Upon review, a lot of that advice has a lot in common. This analysis breaks down the best information I could find and compares it to some of CoScheduleâ€™s open rates, too:Letâ€™s get started.A while back, Garrett analyzed more than 1 million headlines and found that how to, list, and question headlines get more social shares than any other type of blog title.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Not surprisingly, the research for email subject lines suggests that these same three types of messaging tend to perform really well for getting opens.Examples:Recommended Reading:Â Here Are The 101 Catchy Blog Title Formulas That Will Boost Traffic By 438%Thereâ€™s an old adageÂ that helps marketers get into the heads of their audience: Whatâ€™s in it for me?Â Judging from the data,Â answering that question in your email subject line is an awesome way to increase your open rate.You could callÂ this a benefit, appealing to self-interest, or sharing your value proposition. The point is this: Make it clear what your audience will get if they just open your email to experience something they really desire.Examples:Social proof helps your subscribers see themselves being successfulâ€”which works especially wellÂ when they see others rocking your solution. So use your email subject line to appeal to the benefits of stories, case studies, examples, and testimonials scattered throughout your blog post.Examples:A lot ofÂ successful email subject line examples suggest that uniqueness gets opens. Think of including jokes, humor, or something unexpected in your subject lineâ€”anything that arouses curiosity beyond the same-old, same-old.Examples:Recommended Reading:Â How To Build Your Brand With Humor So Youâ€™ll Feel Like A HumanThe fear of missing out is a powerful motivator because it gets your subscribers thinking, â€œWhat do they know that I donâ€™t?â€ Showing a deadline, appealing to a sense of urgency, or even suggesting scarcity in your email subject line can help you increase your opens.Examples:Itâ€™s true that blog posts that feel fresh or essentially reporting on the news in your niche get some of the most social shares of any type of content. In fact, news posts get the most social shares of any type of content (yes, seriously).When you write content that appeals to recent events in your industry, use those facts, subjects, and teasers in your email subject lines to spread the word quickly.Examples:LengthThere is an old-school rule that email subject lines should be about 50 characters long. Since 54% of emails are opened on mobile devices, that seems like itâ€™s still a pretty good idea: The shorter your email subject line, the better.CaseHubSpot calls it the â€œe.e. cummings subject lineâ€ and itâ€™s something copywriting master Joanna WiebeÂ of CopyHackers does consistently: Write your email subject line in all lowercase.Joanna says this approach is more like how a friend or family member would email you, and she offers this advice for email subject line writing:So do yourself a favor and repeat after me:Nobody actually wants to hear from me.They only want to hear from their friends.Your task, then, is to sound as much like their trusted friends, colleagues and/or clients as you canâ€¦ without being trickyâ€¦ or gimmickyâ€¦ or lame.Follow that exercise for every subject line you write, and youâ€™ll get the opens youâ€™re shooting for.Nearly every email service provider lets you send A/B tests for your subject lines. You can do this same exercise forÂ your own subject lines to help you understand why your audience opens and improve all of your future subject lines.Simply write down yourÂ winner and loser from the test, the difference in the results, and scrutinize the reason why your winner performed the best:You can see from these examples that weâ€™ve been trying to strongly appeal to the benefits behind opening the email. Nearly all of these subject lines reuse the blog titles to test for the best-performing headlines. There is still room for improvement!Recommended Reading:Â We A/B Tested Our Email Subject Lines For Months. Hereâ€™s What We Learned.Once you get that email open, how can you get the most clickthroughs from your subscribers to read your blog post? Itâ€™s a good question that deserves a simple and data-driven answer.While your email subject line is one of the primary ways to get email opens, the design of your email can also impact your success.Data says that Neil Patelâ€™s plain text email will get more opens and clickthroughs than MarketingProfsâ€™ HTML-enhanced email.You might think that a designed emailâ€”or HTML-enhanced with a theme of some kindâ€”would increase your opens and clickthroughs. But when HubSpot researched the idea of HTML versus plain text emails, they found that HTML emails actually decreased both their open and clickthrough rates.TheyÂ summarized their findings with a very bold statement:Aside from proper list segmentation, nothing boosts opens and clicks as well as an old school, plain-text email.Super surprising, right?Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?But HubSpotÂ wasnâ€™t the only one to come to that conclusion. DIYthemes also testing a plain text versionÂ of their e-newsletter which their subscribers absolutely loved.And when we at CoSchedule tested several HTML-enhancedÂ emails for the ones we use to announce new blog posts, we found that our plain text versions increased the amount ofÂ opens by 3.5% while decreasing our clickthroughs by 2.12%.At first, you might think that data is a bit misleading, but that 3.5% increase in opens means that more overall subscribers are clicking through to read our content, despite the slight percentage drop in clickthroughs.So why is that?To bring up Joanna Wiebeâ€™s awesome pointÂ from writing subject lines, itâ€™s becauseÂ plain text emails look more authentic and less spammy than HTML-enhanced emails. HubSpot came to the same conclusion in their research, hinting that email filters may be strong enough to weed out over-enhanced emails.IfÂ JoannaÂ and HubSpot are right on those assumptions, then data backs it up. More of your subscribers see email as a 1-to-1Â communication toolÂ that plain text messages seem to reflect while HTML-enhanced emails scream mass marketing.Another reason HTML-enhanced emails may perform slightly worse than plain text emails could be due to the fact that the message in the email itself often begins with gibberish.Let me explain.This is what HTML-enhanced emails look like before you open them:These three examples are HTML-enhanced emails before being clicked through. You can tell thereâ€™s something odd about them from their introductory text.And this is what informal plain text emails look like before you open them:Here are two examples of plain text emails with intriguing and informal introductions.No one wants to feel like youâ€™re marketing to them, but rather, that theyâ€™ve opted in to receiving information that will help them. Email is a way for you to build trust with the audience that is the most likely to convert into real customers. So, how can you build that trust?Just write like you would to a friend.Â Itâ€™s just fine to start an email with Hey there. Let people into your lives a bit like this example of many from Noah Kagan:Noah Kagan uses email to build relationships with his subscribers. You feel like you know him through his informal writing and humor.Now, Iâ€™m not saying you have to be super whimsical like Noah, but I know that heâ€™s built lists that have added up to seven figures of email subscribers (yes, that means more thanÂ a million subscribers). So how does heÂ retain those email subscribers? By treating email as an avenue for a relationship. You read his emails and feel like you know the guy even if youâ€™ve never met him.Focus your messageÂ on explaining the value your subscribers will get whenÂ they visit your blog post. Now, the value isnâ€™t the same as what your post covers, but answers the question,Â whatâ€™s in it for me?There are a few ways to do this:Now, if you donâ€™t know those things, chances areâ€¦ you probably donâ€™t know your audience very well and that may reflect in your content. Here are three simple ways to get the information you need to write more effective emails:AnotherÂ email writing tip involves a bit of simple psychology: Write your email in a way that helps your subscribers feel like theyâ€™ve already made the decision to click through to read your blog post.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?What does that mean?It means usingÂ proven phrases like theseâ€¦â€¦because those phrases assume the subscriber will act on the advice you provide or they will feel the cognitive dissonance of knowingÂ they should have done something but they chose not to.That technique leads directly into a call to action your subscribers can envision themselves doing. For example, hereâ€™s what that could look like for this post specifically:You see how each of those examples suggests that you will do the action, and that when you do, youâ€™ll solve a problem and get the benefits.Recommended ReadingYou just learned a ton of information that will help you get more traffic from email marketing. Hereâ€™s a recap of the process:Where will you start?Click To Tweet

column12: Who are the 100 million people who useÂ Pinterest, with more Pinners coming in every day to make it the fastest growing website by overall member growth?Your audience is present. You just need to share great stuff to discover their interests and help them find you. From there, you can use minimum viable data to understand what theyâ€™re looking for. Then youâ€™ll be able toÂ share even better content.Focus on publishing really good content thatâ€™ll establish you as an expert in your field.The same applies for gaining traction on Pinterest and for growing your follower base in general.Your content core is a special place where you take into consideration what your audience really cares about and combine it with what you want to say.On Pinterest, your boards are where you share your Pins, so name your boards in a unique way.Pinterest suggests you should set your boards up like window displays. You want them to appeal to your audienceâ€™s tastes and also keep them coming back for more. Hereâ€™s a basic look at it from their perspective:Rebekah RadiceÂ takes Pinterestâ€™s advice one step further withÂ a few great ideas thatâ€™ll help you choose awesome names for your boards. Make them eye-catching, keyword rich, and content specific.Sheâ€™s right.Start With:Something likeÂ 80% of the content shared on Pinterest are Repins.When Pinning,Â abide by the 80/20 rule: Share 80% of other peopleâ€™s content and only 20% of your own.For every piece of content that you share, that is yours, Repin four Pins from others.Click To TweetAs you begin, your goals will be:If you look at your blog, Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll find that you have some awesome visuals that are Pin-worthy. There are probably also a few images youÂ could improve.Steps To Improve Your Visuals:After youâ€™ve gone through all your posts, youâ€™ll be able to share the ones that have great visuals to Pinterest. Easy!Recommended Reading:Youâ€™ll need to have high-quality imagery to get noticed. That doesnâ€™t mean you have to be an artist or designer. It just means you have to take some visual guidelines into account when you use Pinterest for marketing.In this day and age, stock photography is out and custom imagery is in! According to Pinterest, Pins should be helpful, beautiful, and actionable. So get creative andÂ use some awesome tools.Your graphics will help you stand out from otherÂ brands, so when you createÂ your imagery, remember that images without faces receive 23% more Repins than those with faces.Curalate found a few key characteristics that can make your Pinterest images successful. Red and orange colored Pins get twice as many Repins than images that are blueâ€”and Pins with multiple dominant colors, too.Â Color can be vital to yourÂ Pinâ€™s success, so do a little research on the emotion behind color, and youâ€™ll do great!Lastly, CuralateÂ found that Pins with smoother, less distracting backgrounds received more traffic. This follows the idea thatÂ simplicity in designÂ is more. Plus, itâ€™s great for mobile viewing!Recommended Reading:Another element you can add to your imagery is an overlay. Text overlays can be great for clarifying an overall message of the Pin since yourÂ photo might have a broad context.Overlays can also be handy when you use themÂ in embedded Pins outside of Pinterest (say embedded into your blog posts).Keep in mind the size of your visual so it displays nicely on Pinterest.When you design your image, choose 735 pixels as your width. You can choose for your Pin to be any length that youâ€™d like it to be.Curalate found that Pins with a 2:3 (1,102Â pixelsÂ tall) or 4:5 aspect ratio received the most traffic. Test out which size works best for you. At CoSchedule, we like to design graphics to specificallyÂ complement our blog posts, so in cases such as an infographic, the longer the better.While itâ€™s important to make your images look awesome, itâ€™s even more important that you understand your content, and the message behind it. Experiment with your Pins so you can stay true to your brand. Donâ€™t be scared to try newÂ design toolsÂ and to share new ideas.Mitt Ray writes about Pinterest a lot. And he compiled some pretty interesting data to help you write better descriptions for your Pins so you can get the attention your content deserves.Mitt suggests that by writing a great Pin, your audience will have a better chance of finding your awesome content.Writing An Awesome Pin:Vincent Ng took a stab at describing the value hashtags provided on Pinterest and how to use them efficiently, coming up with a handful ofÂ solid tips:Recommended Reading: How To Make Writing For Social Media Work For Your BusinessOnly about 75â€“100 characters actually show up in your Pin description in the grid view on a board, so donâ€™t bury the lede: Put the most important information in your description first.Did you know that?Besides the typical â€˜Normalâ€™ Pin and Repins, Pinterest also has Rich Pins, Buyable Pins, and Promoted PinsÂ you can use to enhance your reach.Rich Pins are normal Pins that you can add additional context to, thus the name â€˜Richâ€™ Pins.There are five categories that Rich Pins fall into: product, recipe, article, movie, and place.By creating a Rich Pin, you get to define what the open-graph meta tags are so your Pins automatically populate in the Pinterest categories and searches. Thatâ€™ll help people find your content faster and easier than ever.This can make quite a difference for brands who are trying to sell their product, especially when two million people save Rich Pins to their boards every day!Click To Tweet

column1: Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Buyable Pins are one of Pinterestâ€™s newest features!Buyable Pins have blue buttons that are located up near the â€˜Pin itâ€™ button. They helpÂ you to make a purchase right there without ever having to leave the Pinterest app.Source: Business for PinterestPinterest does this to keep people on Pinterest, so they donâ€™t â€œtake a cut from your sales and you still get to handle shipping and customer service the way you always have.â€Today, any business that uses Shopify has access to Buyable Pins, and those that use Demandware should see this option soon.Pinterest has continued to make changes and updates to promoted Pins in order to make them work even better. Promoted Pins are similar to Facebook Promotions sinceÂ you can purchase them to reach more followers.Promoted Pins increase engagement rates up to 2â€“5% and are cost-per-click. Promoted Pins are only available in the US and in Canada.Did you know that over 80% of all Pins are Repins?Cision noted that several studies have found that you can optimize your Pins for Repinning by using 200â€”300 characters in your Pin description.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?When we Pin atÂ CoSchedule, we include the headline that weÂ created withÂ the headline analyzerÂ in our Pin description. Then we create a Repinning task in our marketing calendar specifically to remind us to Repin great content marketing content to our board. More thanÂ half of our traffic comes from Repinning alone!While Pinning is the first step to growing your presence on Pinterest, these four different kinds of Pins can greatly impact your followers,Â sales, and traffic. Consider what your business is trying to achieve, and pick the one that works best for you!Remember, though, never stop Repinning. Repinning works, and should be a daily practice.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Well, youâ€™ve learned a lot about creating the best content for Pinterestâ€”including how to design your visuals and how to write your Pin descriptions. You even know the right types of Pins thatâ€™ll work best to help you reach your marketing objectives.So now itâ€™s time to optimize your work to make sure you reach the most people every time you Pin.Makes sense, right? If some categories get more browsers, youâ€™ll get more attention for your content when you categorize them accordingly.Here are the most-browsed Pinterest categories:About aÂ year ago, Pinterest also released the most popular categories per day:AndÂ if youâ€™re feeling like any of this just isnâ€™t what you need for your marketing, Pinterest has a great resource for you to see what categories are popular any day youâ€™d like.Â Iâ€™ve found as you refresh the page, new categories appear, which could inspire some ideas for your categorization.We recently took a look at the top 10 studiesÂ on the best times to post on social media. The research has a handful of takeaways to help you get the most out of your new Pins.Quick Sprout suggests that the best day to Pin is on Saturday. Neil Patelâ€™s deeply researched post says that 8â€“11 p.m. on Saturdays should get you the best results. Neil also pulled together some information from several sources that suggestsÂ 2â€“4 a.m.Â and 2â€“4 p.m.Â are awesome times to Pin.Elle & Co. and SurePayroll agreed with Neilâ€™s findings, saying that 8â€“11 p.m. on Saturday is a great time to Pin. SurePayroll also found thatÂ anytime on Saturday morning and Fridays at 3 p.m.Â are great times to Pin,Â too.Data from Pinerly and presented by Social Fresh suggests that anytime from 2â€“4 p.m.Â and 8 p.m.â€“1 a.m.Â are good times to Pin.Comprehensive Data Says The Best Times To Post To Pinterest Are:That seems like a lot of good times, right?The data for Pinterestâ€™s best posting frequency differs quite drastically depending on the source.So whatâ€™s the verdict? Itâ€™s perfectly acceptable to share lots of content every day, including a rich amount of Repins from other Pinners mixed into your overall sharing strategy.Sujan Patel even confirms that Pinning regularly can help you grow your followers.Buzzfeed found out that â€œWhen a reader comes from the Pinterest app on mobile, we show the â€˜Pin itâ€™ button right on top of the image. We found that this increases Pinning by 10 times!â€Yikes, thatâ€™s a big change Buzzfeed saw when their Vice President Of Growth And Data, Dao Nguyen, and her team added a Pin it buttonÂ to their graphics.We have also noticed on our blog here at CoSchedule that when we include a hover button over the images, that we tend to get more Pinterest shares. SumoMe has a great tool to help you do this yourself.Click To Tweet

Want to use Click to Tweet on your blog?Itâ€™s pretty easy to embed single Pins or even entire boards right into your content to help you prove a point. AndÂ this is a way to get more Repins for your content simply because youâ€™ve made it easy to share:;Simply use the Pinterest code generator to grab the widget and embed it right into your blog posts. Done.Brian Honigman provided a Pinterest marketing tip that Peg Fitzpatrick and Rebekah Radice taught him on Social Media Examiner.Essentially, create a great visual in a blog post,Â schedule a Pin, grab the URL of that Pin, and share it on Google+. In your Google+ post, share the link to read your blog post, andÂ also suggest that people Pin the image if they donâ€™t have the time to read it now so they can save it for later.While Rebekah uses this strategy for Google+, Iâ€™m sure it would also work well in emails, Facebook, LinkedIn, and more.Pinterest itself gives this marketing tip, suggesting:Get into a regular cadence of saving Pins to your boards. That way, your audience gets fresh content in their home feed (and they get to know what your brand is all about).As you plan consistent content with your editorial calendar, it just makes sense to share your content consistently on Pinterest. And now that you can schedule your Pins with CoSchedule, thereâ€™s no reason to hold off.Youâ€™ve learned a ton about how to use Pinterest for marketing.You now know:Now, go and implement what youâ€™ve learned into your own content on Pinterest.Click To Tweet

column1: 2016-03-21,http://coschedule.com/blog/html-cheat-sheet-for-content-marketers/,HTML Cheat Sheet For Content Marketers - CoSchedule,"The free blog post headline analyzer will score your overall headline quality and rate its ability to result in social shares, increased traffic, and SEO value.In todayâ€™s economy, youâ€™ve probably heard something about the importance of developing coding skills.However, not all bloggers or content marketers are familiar with HTML.Even among those of us who know a little bit of code, thereâ€™s always more we can learn. In your job, you probably donâ€™t need to know how to build an entire site from the ground up with nothing more than a text editor and your wits.However, if any part of your job involves working in WordPress or another content management system, knowing a little bit of code can be immensely helpful.Click To Tweet
